entry.title: Maximize the value of HR data ‚Äì Introducing People Intelligence
entry.content:
We are excited to introduce people Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud ‚Äì People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud is the new People Analytics solution from SAP based on the fully managed Business Data Cloud that unifies and governs data from SAP SuccessFactors, other SAP and non-SAP sources while preserving its original business context to enable analytics. Designed for HR leaders, HR Business Partners, Managers and many other personas, the solution helps answer some of the most important and critical business questions through prebuilt insight applications.

 The problem

Data is the new currency and HR data has even more potential but, the reality is that most of this data remains fragmented, scattered across silos, locked in incompatible formats, or inaccessible in real time. This fragmentation hinders agility, quick decision-making, and slows innovation. As HR landscapes evolve rapidly and competition intensifies, companies need more than just access to data‚Äîthey need clarity, coherence, and the ability to act on insights with confidence and speed. Additional complexities arise when we want to make this data available for powering AI scenarios and enriching the data leveraging machine learning and Data Science capabilities.

Our solution

To address these data silos and solve these business challenges faced by HR Leaders, we‚Äôre introducing People Intelligence ‚Äì A solution that transforms people, skills, Learning, Recruiting, and talent data into actionable, AI-driven insights. It is a collection of insight Applications around SuccessFactors Core HR, Skills, Recruiting, Learning and talent modules. Many of these insight apps have been built to showcase broad spectrum of insights from these modules and many more to be added covering the other modules as per the published roadmap.

Some of the key Insights that HR leaders can derive through people Intelligence are -

  • Talent Flow Analytics,
  • Knowing if they are building Skills led future-ready organization?
  • Our investments in learning are improving skills proficiencies and how does it impact employee performance?
  • Are we paying for performance and how is our ethnicity and gender pay gap?

 People Intelligence is built on SAP Business Data Cloud(BDC)

As stated earlier, BDC is a fully managed Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solution designed to unify, govern, and make sense of data across the entire business landscape. It brings together SAP and non-SAP data into one trusted, business-ready foundation‚Äîenabling decision-makers access real-time insights with full context. By connecting siloed information through a powerful semantic layer and open data ecosystem, SAP BDC transforms raw data into a strategic asset. BDC brings this powerful functionality of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse, plus managed SAP Databricks, intelligent applications, and data products.

Data Products are curated data sets, the meta data that describes the data set and an API to exchange the data.
Data Products are then used in realising SAP Datasphere Analytic models that power SAP Analytic Cloud stories or Planning scenarios.
Each insight App that is part of People Intelligence is based on SAP curated semantic models, which provide customers with tailored insights and actionable recommendations out-of-the-box.

List of Insight Apps delivered as part of People Intelligence GA:

  • Workforce composition Insights : Visualize workforce composition by role, location, demographics, and org structure, and track how talent flows through the organization by analysing movements, new-hires and terminations data.
  • Skills Insights: See current employee skills, identify role-level gaps (as-is vs. required proficiency), and track which skills are rising or declining across the organization.
  • Workforce Compensation(EC based) Insights: Gain clear compensation visibility by viewing average salaries by role, grade, and location, analysing compa-ratio organization-wide, and comparing pay for terminated employees versus new hires.
  • Recruiting Insights: Reduce time-to-hire and recruitment costs by uncovering the most effective talent sources and ensuring project success by filling open positions faster.
  • Learning Insights: Drive agility across your teams through targeted trainings that closes essential Skills and Proficiency gaps.
  • Performance Insights: Drive productivity and fairness by connecting performance trends to compensation, promotion rate and turnover outcomes.
  • Goals Insights: Ensure goal-setting aligns with organizational strategy and includes progress tracking to completion.
  • Succession Insights: Build a stronger leadership pipeline by evaluating successor readiness, uncovering risk areas, by refining talent pool readiness and succession strategies.
  • Career Development Planning(CDP) Insights: Enhance retention and engagement through tailored, actionable insights into employee development goals.

Through all of these Insight Apps we have enabled access to Data Analyzer which helps the user with a predefined ready-to-run service for multidimensional, pivot styled ad-hoc analysis using our Datasphere models directly.

Another notable feature that is made available in all of the Insight Apps is a A/B comparison utility which helps compare key measure values like headcount etc., by bringing them side by side and by selecting dimensions like location, organization unit, job classification etc., This helps the persona discover the headcount changes between the two locations or by the other selected dimensions in an intuitive manner.

People Intelligence ‚Äì Product Capabilities:

  • Access semantically rich Data Products across all SuccessFactors Modules provided by a scalable SAP managed Data Lake.
  • Access to cross SAP Data Products comprising harmonized data across SAP LOBs discoverable via the central data product catalog.
  • Integrate Data from non-SAP systems into Business Data Cloud.
  • Utilize ready to run insights with out-of-the-box analytical models and dashboards for SuccessFactors modules and cross LOB use-cases.
  • Leverage the power of SAP Business Data Cloud stack to extend the pre-delivered content or create your own analytical application.
  • Enable your data engineers and data scientists to perform pro-code data engineering, data science, custom AI/ML and advanced analytics use-cases.
  • Close the action to insight gap by bringing analytics into the flow of your users in SuccessFactors via Joule.

In summary, People Intelligence helps Drive better HR and business performance with proactively delivered, AI-driven insights and help them stay ahead by continually adapting and optimizing with agility.

What‚Äôs Next

Watch this space for separate blog posts to cover the various insight Apps that we are delivering as part of People Intelligence, the business questions they answer etc.,

Please check the official BDC Roadmap for a comprehensive overview of forthcoming features not just as part of People Intelligence but also BDC.

Resources to know more about People Intelligence:

  • Know more about SAP Business Data Cloud
  • Watch our Success Connect solution deep dive (registration required).
  • Register for our upcoming webinars on People Intelligence: "Drive Better Workforce Decisions with a New Approach to People Analytics" 
  • Visit our Website to know more: https://www.sap.com/people-intelligence
  • Know the potential of People Analytics: IDC Paper: "How AI-Driven Workforce Insights Unlock Value in the Talent Practice for HR Leaders"

entry.title: SAP TechEd Sessions in Berlin and Sydney 2025 by KP Sauer
entry.content:
SAP TechEd 2025

One more week to #SAPTechEd 2025.
I am super excited ‚ú® to speak at this year‚Äôs SAP TechEd in Berlin, and also in Sydney for SAP TechEd on Tour.

ü§© Looking forward to meet and talk to all you data and analytics experts in Berlin or Sydney.

Join me for a variety of sessions this year and gain a comprehensive understanding of our strategic direction and priorities with SAP Business Data Cloud.

 

SAP TechEd in Berlin

Deep Dive Sessions

‚û°Ô∏è  DA204 | The impact of SAP Business Data Cloud on SAP Datasphere users

This session is for all users of SAP Datasphere to better understand the impact with SAP Business Data Cloud and the new options you get within such a new landscape. Rithivika Acharya will give you a demo and we will have some time for Q&A at the end

üîó  https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin/flow/sap/te25/catalog-inperson/page/catalog/session/1753913915410001RQyH

 

‚û°Ô∏è  DA203 | SAP Business Data Cloud: The path forward for SAP Business Warehouse

This session is for all users of SAP BW or BW/4HANA to better understand the impact with SAP Business Data Cloud and exploring the best practices for modernizing with such a new landscape. Domink Kurz will mainly talk here and we will have some time for Q&A at the end.

üîó  https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin/flow/sap/te25/catalog-inperson/page/catalog/session/1753910209205001V1Vm

 

Hands-on Workshop

‚û°Ô∏è  DA264 | SAP Business Data Cloud: Explore the analytical components end to end

This beginner hands-on workshop takes you through the analytical components of the SAP Business Data Cloud solution. Use the SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud solutions to design and build custom scenarios from beginning to end. This session is ideal for technical users seeking to transform data into meaningful business insights. I will be hosting this together with Hannes Keil, Daniel Ingenhaag and Florian Neukirch.

üîó  https://www.sap.com/events/teched/berlin/flow/sap/te25/catalog-inperson/page/catalog/session/1754056240863001fO9w

 

Are you ready? üëâ Register now: https://www.sap.com/events/teched.html

 

SAP TechEd on Tour in Sydney

In Sydney I will be talking live about üöÄ

‚û°Ô∏è  DA806 | SAP Business Data Cloud Solution Road Map

Join me and gain a comprehensive understanding of our strategic direction and priorities with SAP Business Data Cloud. Find out about the product road map and ongoing development in key areas. Learn about our plans to continue to deliver innovation to aid in your data strategy.

 

‚û°Ô∏è  DA100 | An Introduction to SAP Business Data Cloud

Join us for an insightful overview of SAP Business Data Cloud. Discover the key capabilities including seamless integration of SAP and non-SAP data sources, the data product concept, and analytics-ready data across your organization. Learn how SAP Business Data Cloud supports agile decision-making, simplifies complex data challenges, and drives digital transformation.

 

Other than these sessions I will be around the show floor and support hands-on sessions too.
So please be welcome to talk to me as I‚Äôm happy to share my SAP experience during the three days üì¢

Passes to Mastering SAP Collaborate, an SAP TechEd on Tour event, are available online now ‚Äì join me in Sydney on 12 ‚Äì 14 November!

Program and passes at http://sapteched.sydney and best of all you can use code SPEAKER5OFF to save 5% on a pass.

üìç  Where: International Convention Centre, ICC, Darling Harbour, Sydney

entry.title: Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)
entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)

JDBC ‚Äì JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY

Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API :
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access.

Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging
Pagination limits in OData and Ariba APIs can be handled in SAP CPI using a looping process call. I‚Äôll cover this with a clear explanation in an upcoming post.

Goal: Connect CPI to a database used by DataSphere (JDBC) and run a simple read data from the (Analytical Model / Table /View).

For the Write / Delete / Update method, the attached SAP Help Portal Link has syntax in the reference section.

Prerequisites:

  1. SAP DataSphere ‚Äì Subscribed account (‚ö† Trial has limited features, JDBC not supported)
  2. SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Subscribed or Trial (JDBC actions supported)

 

SAP DataSphere Step by Step Guide :

Step

Action / Notes

1. Create a Space

DataSphere ‚Üí Space Management ‚Üí New Space ‚Üí Name it ‚Üí Create.

2. Create Table / Analytical Model

Data Builder ‚Üí In your Space ‚Üí New ‚Üí Table or Analytical Model ‚Üí define fields & data types ‚Üí Save & Publish.
*Verify Table/Model Deployed Successfully. *

3. Prepare / Load Data

Load data manually for testing cases. Otherwise load CSV/import to table via Data Builder/Data Integration.

4. Note Schema & Object Names

Record schema name, table name, and view names for JDBC SQL use.
* Created space name is the SCHEMA name and Collect Table / Model name *

5. Decide Where to Create DB User

If HANA Cloud ‚Üí use HANA Cockpit/DB Explorer. If on-prem DB ‚Üí use DB admin tools or contact DB Admin.
* We are using the HANA cloud system for practical session*

6. Create JDBC DB User

DB admin tool ‚Üí Security/Users ‚Üí New User ‚Üí set username & strong password ‚Üí Save.
*Check Active status of User*

7. Grant Privileges for the DB user

Assign only required privileges (e.g., SELECT for read; add INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE for CRUD). Best practice: create role JDBC_ROLE and assign.

8. Prepare JDBC Connection Details

Gather JDBC URL (e.g.  sample URL from datasphere: z*********-abc.hana.prod-eu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com
Format for CPI JDBC Material:
jdbc:sap://<host>:<port>/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true


SAP Integration Suite Step by Step Guide :

Create a Package & Artifact

  • In CPI ‚Üí Design ‚Üí Create a new package ‚Üí Add an integration flow artifact.
  • ‚úÖ Make sure your CPI user has the required roles to create and access design-time artifacts.

Go to Monitoring ‚Üí JDBC Material

  • In CPI ‚Üí Monitor ‚Üí Integrations and APIs ‚Üí Manage Security ‚Üí JDBC Material

     

  • ‚Üí Add JDBC Data Source. ‚Üí Select HANA cloud

     



  • Provide JDBC URL in the correct format (e.g., jdbc:sap://<hana-host>:443/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true).

     

  • Enter DB username and password (use the dedicated JDBC user created earlier in DataSphere).

     

  • Save and deploy the JDBC material.

Apply JDBC Material in iFlow

  • In your integration flow, configure the JDBC receiver adapter ‚Üí select the JDBC data source created.
  • Use SQL queries (SELECT) in the Processing tab or provide XML query body. Here, I‚Äôm using SQL SELECT * to fetch all records from the table.

 


Step 1: Timer Start
 In this iFlow, the Start Timer is configured with a Simple Schedule ‚Üí None ‚Üí On Deployment, which means the integration flow automatically triggers immediately after deployment.

 


Step 2: Content Modifier
Use this SQL query to fetch all records with the body operation.
 SELECT * FROM "<Schema>"."<Model/TableName>"

 



Step 3: Request Reply & JDBC Receiver Adapter
 ‚Üí Use the deployed JDBC Data Source alias in the JDBC Material in the previous step and set Max records count based on your requirement.
‚Üí JDBC Maximum Records per call:  2,147,483,647

 


Sample data Response from JDBC Connection:

References :
same blog by me for clear picture quality: Integration of SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere using JD... - SAP Community
CPI JDBC ‚Äì XML Query in Body for CRUD Operations (Syntax Guide)
 link:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/payload-and-operation

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in October
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in October

Another month with a great new release delivery ‚ú®

Learn more in my short top features video in October2025 on YouTube üì∫ also including an outlook at SAP TechEd session this year.

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

 

My top features in October

 

Impact of Changes in the Source Objects of an Analytic Model

Changing, saving, and re-deploying a data builder object again will trigger a status change of any analytic model that uses that object. The analytic model status will change to either ‚ÄúChanges to Deploy‚Äù or ‚ÄúDesign Time Error‚Äù, depending on which change has been made (compatible or incompatible changes). This gives you better transparency in change control handling of your models.

 

Converting a Data Flow Into a Replication Flow and/or Transformation Flow

When your data flow is eligible to be converted into a transformation flow or a replication flow coupled with a transformation flow, a banner will be displayed in the data flow editor. Using a replication flow and/or a transformation flow will allow you to benefit from improved connectivity, access to delta load processing, and enhanced resiliency and scalability.
‚û°Ô∏è   More information

 

Technical User to Manage Tasks via CLI

You can now use OAuth clients with the technical user purpose to manage tasks via the command line interface based on the roles and spaces you assign to the client.
‚û°Ô∏è   More information.

 

 

 

SAP TechEd 2025

There are many sessions about SAP Business Data Cloud and also SAP Datasphere at SAP TechEd 2025. Some are part of the virtual TechEd and others like for instance the onsite hands-on sessions are exclusive for people attending in Berlin.

 

 

My favorite blogs in October

My colleague @Max_Gander wrote two nice blogs about the new feature with live versions in planning, which I think is a one of the best features I have seen all next to seamless planning itself:
‚û°Ô∏è   Live Versions from an SQL Source for SAP Analytics Cloud Planning
‚û°Ô∏è   Unlocking the Next Chapter of Seamless Planning in SAP Business Data Cloud with Live Versions

 

People Intelligence is one of the latest applications offered as part of SAP Business Data Cloud. @blberger has written a informative blog about its general availability and offers many useful links to further details about this offering:
‚û°Ô∏è   Maximize the value of HR data ‚Äì Introducing People Intelligence
@VenkatPSis looking at the same topic from a use case perspective and explains the problems which can be solved using this application:
‚û°Ô∏è   People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud is Generally Available!

 

@hozumihighlight another interesting capability we recently delivered as part of SAP BDC, which is called BDC Connect and it helps expand the zero copy delta sharing to external systems: 
‚û°Ô∏è   SAP BDC Connect: SAP elevates bidirectional zero-copy data sharing with game-changing partnerships

 

Keep on brining these valuable blogs @FernandaFroelich. On the one hand she extend her blog series on SAP Databricks by looking more detailed on user and roles with Databricks:
‚û°Ô∏è   Get started with SAP Databricks: Users and roles
On the other hand, she helps you to better understand the consumption monitoring in SAP BDC:
‚û°Ô∏è   How to monitor consumption for SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and its components?

entry.title: SAP HANA Cloud Becomes Agentic: Introducing Discovery Agent & Data Agent
entry.content:
The Challenge

Enterprises today work with massive volumes of data spread across tables, views, JSON collections, graphs, and text. Yet most users don‚Äôt know where that data lives or how to access it efficiently. Building a bridge between business questions and the underlying technical data model often requires deep schema knowledge and SQL expertise.

At the same time, users expect to ‚Äútalk to their data‚Äù, to search, ask, and get answers without navigating complex structures. But creating such experiences has often been challenging. Data is often siloed, metadata is hard to navigate, and the context needed to connect insights is missing.

The Innovation: Discovery Agent and Data Agent in SAP HANA Cloud (planned QRC1 2026)

At SAP TechEd 2025, SAP HANA Cloud takes a major step forward by becoming agentic and introducing a suite of agents designed to simplify how people discover and interact with data.

In this blog, the focus will be on the Discovery Agent and the Data Agent.
Together, they make it easier for agent users to find the right data objects, understand relationships, and generate the right queries, all without needing deep technical or SQL knowledge.

Discovery Agent: Exploring data context

The Discovery Agent helps users find and understand the data available in SAP HANA Cloud. It explores the HANA catalog using a Knowledge Graph that exposes how objects relate to one another, making it easy to locate relevant datasets without manually browsing schemas. When users describe what they need, like for example, project details or customer transactions, the Discovery Agent can identify the right data sources based on context, relationships, and annotations. Under the hood, the agent generates SPARQL queries on the RDF graph of HANA objects, revealing how data structures connect.

Data Agent: Turning intent into executable queries

Once the relevant data objects are found, the Data Agent takes over.
It translates natural language intent into executable queries, such as SQL. Users can simply describe what they want to retrieve, for instance, ‚Äúshow my current projects with partner involvement‚Äù and the Data Agent generates and executes the corresponding query.

By combining discovery and query generation, these agents make data exploration seamless: the Discovery Agent provides context, while the Data Agent delivers answers.

Powered by the SAP HANA Cloud Custom Database Objects Knowledge Graph (planned QRC1 2026)

At the core of these agents lies the Custom Database Objects Knowledge Graph: an RDF graph automatically built from system catalog that captures tables, columns, relationships, and annotations. It provides the semantic layer needed for exploration, AI grounding, and graph-based reasoning, forming the foundation for richer, AI ready data discovery in SAP HANA Cloud. What used to take days of manual modeling can now be done automatically in minutes.

Create a custom database objects knowledge graph on SAP HANA Cloud Central

This Knowledge Graph allows agents to reason about data, to understand how entities connect, what relationships exist, and which attributes are relevant. It is the foundation that enables both discovery and querying to work contextually and at scale.

 

How It Works

Imagine a business user who doesn‚Äôt know the database schema or table names, they simply have a question in mind and want to ‚Äútalk to the database.‚Äù

For example, they might ask: ‚ÄúList all customers with their sales conversion probability and related details?‚Äù

Here‚Äôs what happens behind the scenes:

  1. The Discovery Agent searches the Database Objects Knowledge Graph to identify which tables and views contain the relevant data.
  2. The Data Agent then uses that information to generate a query that retrieves the results without any manual lookup or SQL writing required.

In a few seconds, the user receives a clear answer. The process feels conversational, even though the agents are performing complex discovery and query generation under the hood.

Ask a Natural Language Query on your database objects, via Joule in SAP HANA Cloud Central

Explore insights built on the actual database objects and relationships in your SAP HANA Cloud instance.

 

Enables Data Discovery

With the Discovery and Data Agents, SAP HANA Cloud transforms metadata into a living semantic layer that spans its multi-model engines. The ‚Äúagent users‚Äù can now query their data environment conversationally, explore hidden relationships, and even surface annotations and sample values to guide analytics. Together, these agents transform SAP HANA Cloud from a static data platform into a dynamic environment where users can reason, explore, and interact with data naturally.

Looking Ahead: Context and Memory for Agents (Product Vision)

The journey toward an agentic SAP HANA Cloud is just beginning. As these capabilities evolve, context and long-term memory will play a key role in shaping the next generation of agents. Future agents will not only discover and query data but also retain context from previous interactions, remembering what was asked, which datasets were used, and what outcomes were returned. Over time, this could enable more natural and connected conversations with data, where insights evolve instead of starting from scratch each time.
This concept of Agentic Memory will help create more continuous and connected user experiences, all while leveraging HANA Cloud‚Äôs trusted data management and governance foundation.

Conclusion:

Together, these agents make SAP HANA Cloud the foundation for a new generation of secure, context-aware, and agent-driven data experiences.

For agent users, this means:

  • A unified way to access data and metadata.
  • Natural-language querying through familiar protocols (MCP).
  • The potential for context persistence across multi-turn conversations.
  • A path toward AI-grounded data exploration and graph-enhanced analytics.

With that, it‚Äôs certain: SAP HANA Cloud is THE database for SAP‚Äôs AI-native software architecture. For additional updates and announcements from SAP TechEd 2025, check @thomashammer 's blogpost here

entry.title: Agentic Databases for Data Scientists: SAP HANA Cloud Will Equip You with a Team
entry.content:
During my tenure as a data practitioner, I often preferred my own database to produce mission-critical calculations. The journey of such an analysis usually began with a single purpose, like informing a business process manager or a change of parameters to optimize a back-end process. Regardless of the original scope, the need to operationalize the logic often followed.

data professional in front of two monitors

Moonlighting as a DBA was nice, admittedly, because I could manage my databases with minimal process obstacles . However, the time lost searching documentation and stuck in trial-error loops of administrative commands only increased the delivery pressure, as deadlines are often unforgiving. I very quickly learned that while I was certainly capable of performing a dual role, I could not be great at both. The expectations of my job demanded data analysis excellence, while I desperately sought after administrative competency.

Last week at SAP TechEd 2025, the SAP HANA Cloud team made a few significant announcements. One very notable set of features is the introduction of the agentic database concept. Simply illustrated and grounded in my scenario, the use of AI agents could give me the best of both worlds ‚Äì autonomy and scale. Applying the example, imagine the productivity benefits associated with giving every data science professional a dedicated team of agentic colleagues ‚Äì administrator, data analyst, and a multi-model specialist.

SAP HANA Cloud agents

For those who prefer the native use of a database, consider the upcoming agentic features of SAP HANA Cloud:

  • The discovery agent provides insight into the objects within the database using a knowledge graph for more efficient semantic lookups.
  • The multi-model agent augments with the specialist knowledge needed to use the advanced analysis engines.
  • The data agent supplements the need for SQL with natural language queries.
  • The admin agent assists with the analysis and optimization of the database.

SAP HANA Cloud enhances all data professionals with agentic teammates. Thanks additionally to in-memory speed, machine learning and AI libraries, access to multi-model engines, data-tiering, and the ability to scale, this cloud database provides the much-desired resources to build autonomous, intelligent, and responsive solutions that drive business process excellence.

To learn more about functionality and availability ...

entry.title: Sailing Analytics Goes Open Source
entry.content:
On October 20, 2025, SAP published the source code of the Sailing Analytics solution and its companion apps (Sailing Race Manager, Buoy Pinger, Sail Insight) on GitHub under the Apache 2.0 license. This finally allows all interested parties to contribute to the solution, and optionally even host it themselves. 

This was a logical next step for the project and remains in-line with SAP‚Äôs open source principles described in the SAP Open Source Manifesto. It lays out a vision where open source drives innovation through collaboration and empowers communities through openness. 

What Sailing Analytics Does 

The Sailing Analytics solution helps comment and analyze sailing regattas by combining data from satellite tracking, wind sensors, and decisions by the race committee into live results and analyses. As a cloud solution, it scales from small cost-efficient club-level events to the most visible regattas at the Olympic Summer Games in Tokyo (2020/2021) and Paris (2024), serving hundreds of thousands of concurrent viewers across several regions worldwide. It powers the world's largest sailing tracking database with wind data and proper score boards (https://sapsailing.com). See it in action, live from the upcoming Youth World Championships 2025 in Vilamoura, Portugal taking place December 12-20, 2025, at https://youthworlds2025.sapsailing.com. 

While Sailing Analytics started in the domain of one-design dinghy sailing with a specific focus on Olympic classes, over time it has evolved into many other areas of the complex sport. This includes different handicap formats with support for handicap-based live rankings, and a variety of scoring systems.

 

The solution can be configured to work with different systems for position tracking, wind sensors, external regatta management tools, and official scoring systems. Through its RESTful API it is possible to integrate more external tools and components without a need to change the sources. For tighter integrations, such as tracking systems and administration interfaces, a connector architecture exists that allows developers to extend the solution accordingly.  

Collaboration Models 

With the code base now being released under a permissive open-source license, several new collaboration opportunities have opened.  

In particular: 

  • Sensor technology providers can implement connectivity 
  • Federations, class associations and event hosts can work on new formats and scoring options to be supported 
  • Research institutions can extend the solution for their specific projects and in-depth analysis 
  • Sailing enthusiasts with a background in IT or graphic design can contribute to all layers and aspects of the solution 

Find a Neutral Entity as the New Home 

In the long run, we plan to move this project to a neutral entity, such as a foundation, to collaborate with more individuals and teams to ensure neutral governance. In a foundation, this solution will benefit from established processes for running open-source projects and structures for collaboration that allow interested stakeholders to easily shape the project‚Äôs future together.

 

Join Us for a Technical Webinar 

We plan a one-hour webcast on this subject for the beginning of 2026. There you will learn about the status of the project, the potential going forward, and the concrete ways for you to participate, contribute, and collaborate. Let us know if you are interested either in the comments or by using the email below. Please find more details here. 

For those who can‚Äôt wait, please also use the project‚Äôs discussion board or send an e-mail to support@sapsailing.com to learn more.

entry.title: Slaying the S/4 HANA Dual Maintenance & interim State Monster: Palantir's Trick to Treat Your Budget
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION

Imagine trying to rebuild your entire house, from the foundations up, while still living in it and running your daily life! That's the scale of the challenge many global enterprises are embracing as they transition from SAP ECC to S/4HANA. It's not just a tech upgrade; it's arguably the most significant transformation they'll undertake this decade.

Given the sheer size, the intricate sap integration web of operations with other systems, and all those unique regional needs, no one wants to risk bringing their business to a standstill. That's why most organisations are wisely choosing a thoughtful, multi-year, phased rollout.

Migrating from SAP ECC to S/4HANA is one of the most significant transformations many global enterprises will undertake this decade. Given the scale, complexity, and regional dependencies involved, most organizations opt for a multi-year, phased rollout to minimize business disruption.

While this approach minimizes business disruption, it introduces a costly challenge: dual maintenance the need to maintain, reconcile, and synchronize data and processes across both ECC and S/4 systems during the transition period.

In this post, we‚Äôll explore how Palantir‚Äôs data integration and digital twin capabilities can dramatically reduce those interim costs, streamline operations, and accelerate time-to-value.

The Dual Maintenance Dilemma

During a staggered rollout, some business units run on ECC while others move to S/4HANA. This creates temporary but expensive complexity:

  • Duplicate data maintenance across ECC and S/4 systems (e.g., master data, pricing conditions, bills of material)

  • Parallel reporting landscapes, as analytics must draw from both systems

  • Integration bridges required to maintain end-to-end process continuity (order-to-cash, procure-to-pay, etc.)

  • Reconciliation overhead to ensure financial and operational consistency

These efforts can add millions in IT and business costs annually during the rollout.

What Palantir does differently for Interim State?

Rapid Data Integration: Foundry excels at ingesting and integrating vast amounts of disparate data (structured, unstructured, streaming) from various source systems (legacy databases, cloud applications, IoT devices, spreadsheets, etc.) into a single, coherent data asset. This significantly reduces the need for manual data manipulation or temporary data warehouses.

Dynamic Data Models (Ontology): Instead of static data models, Foundry builds a dynamic "ontology" , a living, interconnected representation of an organisation's real-world entities (e.g., customers, assets, products, events) and their relationships. This provides a unified, real-time "digital twin" of the organisation's operations. This eliminates the "interim state" of fragmented data views and manual reconciliation.

Data Lineage and Governance: Foundry automatically tracks data lineage, providing transparency on where data comes from and how it's transformed. This builds trust in the data and reduces the need for manual validation steps often found in interim processes.

Accelerated Application Development: Users can build operational applications, dashboards, and analytical tools directly on top of this integrated ontology without needing to move data to separate systems. This bypasses the need for bespoke, temporary solutions that often characterise an interim state.

System of Engagement over System of Record": Palantir often acts as a "system of engagement" or "system of analysis" that sits on top of existing "systems of record." It doesn't require organisations to immediately rip and replace their legacy systems. Instead, it integrates data from these systems, allowing them to continue functioning while providing a modern, unified operational layer.

In essence, Palantir Foundry's unique value lies in its ability to rapidly integrate and harmonise data from across an enterprise into a dynamic, operational ontology. This provides a single, coherent source of truth and a platform for building applications, thereby eliminating the need for costly "interim states" and allowing organisations to strategically reduce or retire redundant systems, thus cutting "dual maintenance running costs".

Palantir: A Unified Data and Process Layer

Palantir Foundry offers a powerful solution: instead of forcing every application, report, and integration to connect separately to ECC and S/4HANA, organizations can use Palantir as a single harmonized data layer across both systems.

This creates a ‚Äúdigital twin‚Äù of the enterprise that abstracts away the differences between ECC and S/4, providing unified access to operational and analytical data without redundant maintenance.

How Palantir Helps Reduce Interim Dual Maintenance Costs

1. Unified Data Model for ECC and S/4

Palantir can connect directly to both ECC and S/4HANA systems (via SAP connectors, OData services, or data extracts) and harmonize the key master and transactional data - customers, materials, vendors, G/L accounts into a single, consistent data model.

Example: Instead of maintaining customer hierarchies in both ECC and S/4, Palantir can ingest them from ECC and apply transformation logic that reflects the new S/4 model. Downstream systems (analytics, planning, compliance) can consume the Palantir layer directly, avoiding the need to replicate changes twice.

Impact: Reduces data duplication and manual harmonization efforts by up to 60‚Äì70% during migration.

2. Process Continuity Through Digital Twins

Palantir‚Äôs Operational Data Layer (ODL) enables enterprises to create a digital twin of critical business processes  such as order-to-cash or supply chain flows  across ECC and S/4 boundaries.

Example: Imagine a company where Europe has migrated to S/4 but North America is still on ECC. Orders may flow from ECC customers to S/4 production plants. Instead of building and maintaining multiple custom SAP interfaces, Palantir can serve as the process bridge ‚Äî integrating order, inventory, and delivery data in real-time to ensure seamless visibility and coordination.

Impact: Cuts custom integration and reconciliation costs while ensuring consistent KPIs across regions.

3. Harmonized Analytics Layer

Reporting is one of the biggest pain points during phased migration. Palantir provides a centralized analytics layer where ECC and S/4 data can be combined, transformed, and visualized using the same semantic logic.

Example: Finance teams can view a consolidated P&L across both systems without reconciling chart of accounts manually. Palantir‚Äôs ontology layer standardizes financial attributes (cost centers, profit centers, etc.) across systems, enabling consistent reporting months  or years  before full migration completes.

Impact: Eliminates need for maintaining dual SAP BW or SAC models during rollout.

4. Accelerated Master Data Migration

By connecting to both source (ECC) and target (S/4) systems, Palantir can simulate and validate master data transformations in advance. This reduces rework during each migration wave.

Example: For materials management, Palantir can pre-map ECC material master attributes to S/4‚Äôs simplified data model, identify inconsistencies, and validate against business rules all without touching production systems.

Impact: Reduces downtime and errors during each cutover, saving time and resources.

5. Continuous Value Delivery During Transition

Palantir‚Äôs modular architecture allows business users to build analytics and decision applications that remain valid even after the migration is complete. This protects investments in data products and dashboards, reducing re-implementation costs post-S/4 go-live.

Illustrative Scenario: A Global Manufacturing Company

Context: A global manufacturer is migrating from ECC to S/4HANA over 4 years. Europe goes live first, while APAC and North America remain on ECC.

Challenges:

  • Global financial consolidation required across mixed systems

  • Duplicate master data maintenance in multiple systems

  • Integration pain for global supply chain visibility

Palantir Solution:

  • Build a unified Palantir data model integrating ECC and S/4 data

  • Create operational dashboards for global supply chain using this harmonized data

  • Maintain a single master data governance workflow through Palantir‚Äôs ontology layer

Outcome:

  • 50% reduction in IT maintenance costs during rollout

  • Single version of truth for finance and operations

  • Seamless reporting continuity across systems

In essence, Palantir allows you to ‚Äúrun as one‚Äù even while you‚Äôre still migrating to one.

#SAP #S4HANA, #Palantir, #DigitalTransformation, #CloudTransformation, #DualMaintenance, #SAPMigration, #EnterpriseMigration, #ERPStrategy, #BusinessTransformation #ERPTraansformation

entry.title: SAP RPT-1 Context Model vs. Training Classical Models: The Models Battle (Python Hands-on)
entry.content:
üí•The Models Battle

Predictive modeling is becoming a built-in capability across SAP, improving how teams handle forecasting, pricing, and planning. Many SAP professionals, however, aren‚Äôt machine-learning specialists, and traditional models often demand extensive setup, tuning, and repeated training, which slows down new ideas.

SAP RPT-1 offers a simpler path. It‚Äôs a pretrained model from SAP, also available in an OSS version, that lets developers and consultants produce predictions with far less technical effort, no deep ML background required.

I've explored SAP RPT-1 hands-on, comparing it with traditional regressors using Python and a real public vehicles price dataset. 

Goal: To see (as a non Data Scientist) how SAP RPT-1 behaves in practice, what advantages and limits it shows, and when it could make sense in a predictive scenario.

Usually for real-world scenario, the right approach would be consume the SAP RPT-1 though the available and simplified API, but for studies proposal and fair comparision over othe traditional ML models, the OSS fits perfectly for it:

ü§î SAP RPT-1 vs Traditional Machine Learning - Core Differences

Before diving into the code, let‚Äôs quickly revisit how traditional ML models work:

  • Training-based models like Random Forest, LightGBM, and Linear Regression learn patterns directly from data. 
  • They require hundreds or thousands of examples to tune their internal parameters.
  • Their performance depends heavily on data quantity and quality.
  • The more relevant examples they see, the smarter they get.

On the other hand, SAP RPT-1 follows a different philosophy. It‚Äôs part of the RPT (Representational Predictive Transformer) family, pretrained on a wide variety of business and contextual data. This means:

  • You don‚Äôt "train" it in the traditional sense. Instead, it uses context embeddings to predict outcomes.
  • It can be used immediately, even with smaller datasets.
  • The OSS version allows developers to experiment directly in Python.
  • No special SAP backend required.

Outcome: Traditional ML models learn from high amount of data. SAP RPT-1 already knows how to deal with small context amount of data.

üñ• The Experiment - Setup & Dataset 

Spoiler
Don't worry on "playing puzzles" copying + pasting code below. The full version is available for download at end!

To make this comparison tangible, I built a simple yet realistic Python experiment to predict vehicle selling prices using a public dataset containing car attributes like make, model, year, transmission, and mileage.

Why vehicle pricing? Because it‚Äôs an intuitive example where both traditional machine learning and pretrained AI models can be applie, and it helps visualize how prediction quality evolves as the sample size grows.

This entire analysis runs on a local Python environment with the following stack:

import os
import gc
import warnings
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from datetime import datetime
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.metrics import r2_score
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import LabelEncoder
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sap_rpt_oss import SAP_RPT_OSS_Regressor
import lightgbm as lgb
  • pandas and numpy for data manipulation
  • scikit-learn for classical ML regressors (Random Forest, Linear Regression)
  • LightGBM for gradient boosting comparison
  • sap_rpt_oss ‚Äî the open-source Python version of SAP‚Äôs RPT-1 model
  • matplotlib for all visualizations

SAP RPT-1 OSS can be downloaded installed following official Hugging Face: https://huggingface.co/SAP/sap-rpt-1-oss?library=sap-rpt-1-oss . Python can be installed with executable download on Windows, or via Home Brew for Mac and apt commands for Linux. Libraries dependencies can be downloaded with pip commands. Googling it may not be a road blocker.

We use a sample vehicle sales dataset. The complete file is about to 88Mb but for such experiment a restricted sample of 20k as it's more than enough to prove our the concept, still it's faster and consuming less computing resources.

FeatureDescription
yearVehicle model year
makeBrand (e.g., Toyota, Ford, BMW)
modelSpecific model name
bodyType (SUV, Sedan, etc.)
transmissionGear type
odometerVehicle mileage
color, interiorVisual attributes
sellingpriceThe target variable to predict

üìä Dataset Download: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/syedanwarafridi/vehicle-sales-data?resource=download 

The dataset is loaded and preprocessed in a few simple steps:

df = pd.read_csv("car_prices.csv").sample(n=20000, random_state=42)

# Fill missing values for categorical columns
fill_defaults = {
    'make': 'Other', 'model': 'Other', 'color': 'Other',
    'interior': 'Unknown', 'body': 'Unknown', 'transmission': 'Unknown'
}
for col, val in fill_defaults.items():
    df[col] = df[col].fillna(val)

X = df[["year", "make", "model", "body", "transmission", "odometer", "color", "interior"]]
y = df["sellingprice"]

At this point, the stage is set:

  • The data is clean.
  • The environment is ready.
  • All models, traditionals and SAP RPT-1, are ready to be tested under identical conditions.

ü§ñ Training the Models - Three different ones

With the dataset ready, the next step is to run each model under the same conditions: same features, same target, same train/test split and same random seed. This ensures the comparison is fair and repeatable.

We evaluate prediction performance using R¬≤ (coefficient of determination), which indicates how much of the price variation the model can explain (1.0 = perfect prediction).

Training Model #1 - Random Forest

Random Forest is often the first model used in tabular ML. It works by creating many decision trees and averaging their predictions. Before training, categorical variables need to be label-encoded into numbers, a common requirement for classical ML models:

def train_random_forest(X, y):
    X = X.copy()
    cat_cols = ["make", "model", "body", "transmission", "color", "interior"]
    le = LabelEncoder()

    for col in cat_cols:
        X[col] = le.fit_transform(X[col].astype(str).fillna("Unknown"))

    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = RandomForestRegressor(
        n_estimators=150, max_depth=20, random_state=42, n_jobs=-1
    )

    try:
        model.fit(X_train, y_train)
        preds = model.predict(X_test)
        r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)
    except Exception as e:
        preds, r2 = np.zeros_like(y_test), 0

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Up to 50 rows:

Up to 7067 rows:

Live view

 

Training Model #2 - LightGBM

LightGBM is one of the most powerful models for tabular data. Unlike Random Forest (many independent trees), LightGBM builds trees sequentially, each correcting the errors of the previous one. It supports categorical features natively, which simplifies preprocessing.

def train_lightgbm(X, y):
    X = X.copy()
    cat_cols = ["make", "model", "body", "transmission", "color", "interior"]
    for col in cat_cols:
        X[col] = X[col].astype(str).fillna("Unknown").astype("category")

    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = lgb.LGBMRegressor(
        n_estimators=500, learning_rate=0.05, num_leaves=31,
        subsample=0.8, colsample_bytree=0.8, random_state=42
    )

    try:
        model.fit(X_train, y_train, categorical_feature=cat_cols)
        preds = model.predict(X_test)
        r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)
    except Exception:
        preds, r2 = np.zeros_like(y_test), 0

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Up to 50 rows:

Up to 7067 rows:

Live view

Training Model #3 - Linear Regression

Not fancy and even not complex, Linear Regression provides a baseline that shows: ‚ÄúIf the relationship between attributes and price is roughly linear, how well can a simple model perform?‚Äù

def train_linear_model(X, y):
    X = X.copy()
    cat_cols = ["make", "model", "body", "transmission", "color", "interior"]
    for col in cat_cols:
        X[col] = LabelEncoder().fit_transform(X[col].astype(str).fillna("Unknown"))

    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = LinearRegression()
    X_train = X_train.fillna(X_train.mean(numeric_only=True))
    X_test = X_test.fillna(X_test.mean(numeric_only=True))

    try:
        model.fit(X_train, y_train)
        preds = model.predict(X_test)
        r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)
    except Exception:
        preds, r2 = np.zeros_like(y_test), 0

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Up to 50 rows:

Up to 7067 rows:

Live view

üèÅ SAP RPT-1 OSS: Context Model

This is where things get interesting. SAP RPT-1 does not rely on learning patterns from the dataset. Instead, it uses a pretrained transformer architecture to infer relationships directly through context embeddings. Lean and simple, "for non-Data Science PhD":

def train_sap_rpt1(X, y):
    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(
        X, y, test_size=default_test_size, random_state=42
    )

    model = SAP_RPT_OSS_Regressor(max_context_size=8192, bagging=8)
    model.fit(X_train, y_train)

    preds = model.predict(X_test)
    r2 = r2_score(y_test, preds)

    return [preds, r2, y_test]

Up to 50 rows:

Up to 2055 rows:

Live view

 

üîé Running Experiments at Multiple Sample Sizes

This section breaks down how the iterative experiment loop works, why the SAP RPT-1 OSS model has a max-context limit, and how performance changes as we scale up the dataset. By running the same models across several sample sizes, we can see where traditional ML shines, where RPT-1 stays competitive, and how both behave as the data grows.

sample_sizes = np.linspace(50, len(X), 200, dtype=int)
results, max_r2_rpt1, max_sample_rpt1 = [], 0, 0

for n in sample_sizes:
    idx = np.random.choice(len(X), n, replace=False)
    X_sample, y_sample = X.iloc[idx], y.iloc[idx]


    # SAP RPT-1 OSS (limited sample size)
    if n <= rpt1_limit:
        rpt_res = train_sap_rpt1(X_sample, y_sample)
        fn = plot_predictions(rpt_res[2], rpt_res[0], rpt_res[1], "SAP_RPT1", n)
        video_frames["SAP_RPT1"].append(fn)
        r2_rpt1 = rpt_res[1]
        max_r2_rpt1 = max(max_r2_rpt1, r2_rpt1)
    else:
        r2_rpt1 = max_r2_rpt1
        if max_sample_rpt1 == 0:
            max_sample_rpt1 = n

    # Train and plot models
    rf_res = train_random_forest(X_sample, y_sample)
    fn = plot_predictions(rf_res[2], rf_res[0], rf_res[1], "RandomForest", n)
    video_frames["RandomForest"].append(fn)

    lgb_res = train_lightgbm(X_sample, y_sample)
    fn = plot_predictions(lgb_res[2], lgb_res[0], lgb_res[1], "LightGBM", n)
    video_frames["LightGBM"].append(fn)

    lin_res = train_linear_model(X_sample, y_sample)
    fn = plot_predictions(lin_res[2], lin_res[0], lin_res[1], "LinearModel", n)
    video_frames["LinearModel"].append(fn)

    results.append((n, rf_res[1], r2_rpt1, lgb_res[1], lin_res[1]))

    # Early stop if traditional model reaches SAP RPT-1
    if rf_res[1] >= max_r2_rpt1 or lgb_res[1] >= max_r2_rpt1 or lin_res[1] >= max_r2_rpt1:
        break
    gc.collect()

This loop compares SAP RPT-1 OSS with traditional ML models as sample sizes increase. Each iteration randomly selects a subset of the data and trains all models on the same slice for a fair comparison. SAP RPT-1 can only run up to its max-context limit, so once the sample size exceeds that threshold, it stops retraining and simply carries forward its best R¬≤. The traditional models continue training at every step. The loop ends early when any traditional model matches or surpasses RPT-1‚Äôs best score, making the experiment efficient while showing how performance evolves as data grows.

üîö Conclusion and Final Thoughts

 SAP RPT-1 OSS stands out because it performs well with small datasets, requires minimal code, and can generate useful predictions with just an API call and a bit of context. This makes it ideal for jump-starting predictive use cases early on, delivering fast business value without a full ML pipeline. Traditional models, however, still shine when projects mature, data grows, and fine-tuned control becomes important. It‚Äôs not about choosing one over the other, but understanding where each approach brings the most value.

 Aspect SAP RPT-1 OSS Traditional ML (RF, LGBM, Linear)
Data RequirementsLow (performs well with small samples)Medium/High (performance scales with data
Setup EffortMinimal (API call + context)Higher (preprocessing, encoding, tuning)
Training ProcessNone (pretrained context model)Full training pipeline required
Speed to InsightsVery fastModerate to slow
Best Use CaseEarly-stage predictive cases, quick baselinesMature pipelines, high control and customization
FlexibilityLimited tuning / plug-and-playHighly customizable
Business ValueImmediate, fast, accessibleStrong when optimized and scaled

This experiment highlights a simple truth: SAP RPT-1 isn‚Äôt here to replace traditional ML, it jump-starts it. With a pretrained, context-driven approach, RPT-1 delivers fast, reliable insights with very little data and almost no setup. Traditional models still excel in mature, data-rich scenarios, but RPT-1 shines as a rapid accelerator and early-value generator inside SAP landscapes.

üí¨Open for Exchange

If you're testing RPT-1, exploring predictive cases, or want the full code, feel free to reach out.
Happy to connect, compare experiences, and push this topic forward together.

entry.title: The Added Value of SAP Business Data Cloud with Databricks, Snowflake and MS Fabric
entry.content:
There as been a lot of partnership announcement lately broadening the extend of SAP Business Data Cloud capabilities and integration.

In today‚Äôs multi-platform data landscapes, organizations are increasingly blending SAP and non-SAP data to drive insights, automate decision-making, and accelerate innovation. But combining the trusted semantics of SAP with the scalability and flexibility of modern cloud data platforms is not always straightforward.
This is where SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)‚Äîpowered by SAP Datasphere‚Äîdelivers extraordinary strategic value. And with BDC connect, SAP takes cross-ecosystem integration even further, enabling a harmonized, governed, bidirectional data fabric that works seamlessly with platforms such as Microsoft Fabric, Snowflake, and Databricks.

Why SAP Business Data Cloud Changes the Game

SAP Business Data Cloud is designed to bridge the historical gap between SAP‚Äôs rich business context and the broader data landscape. It moves beyond simple data replication or extraction: it preserves SAP‚Äôs business semantics, delivers harmonized models, and enables federated consumption with minimal data movement, to take on-time decisions based on data.

Here‚Äôs what makes it transformative:

1. Business-ready data out of the box

SAP systems contain deeply embedded logic‚Äîcurrency conversions, hierarchies, master data relationships, authorizations, time-dependencies‚Äînone of which carry over when raw tables are moved into a data lake or modern warehouse.

Throughts Business Data Cloud, SAP provides out-of-the box Data Products that automatically collects and exposes SAP data with meaning intact, avoiding:

  • custom semantic reconstruction

  • brittle pipelines

  • manual hierarchical transformations

This dramatically reduces time-to-insight for downstream analytics platforms.

2. Governance, lineage, and security at enterprise scale

BDC maintains:

  • end-to-end lineage

  • SAP role-based security

  • metadata enrichment

  • business catalogs

This ensures that downstream platforms consume trusted, governed data, not raw or misinterpreted tables.

How BDC combines with Microsoft Fabric, Snowflake, and Databricks

While SAP Business Data Cloud is a fully standalone powerful platform for data and analytics, customers may have chosen another technology to handle some aspects of their data storage and governance. Providing a partnership with these platforms enables to propose a deep integration within a broader ecosystem.

- SAP Business Data Cloud + Microsoft Fabric

With BDC connect, Fabric can tap directly into SAP semantic models with a zero-copy capabilities enabling to successfully combine SAP and non-SAP data and leverging the existing features of Microfot Fabric.

- SAP Business Data Cloud + Snowflake

Snowflake excels at multi-cloud elasticity, secure data sharing, and workload isolation. BDC complements Snowflake through:

  • SAP-optimized data contracts exposed as Snowflake-ready datasets

  • Replication or federation with preserved semantics

  • Accelerated development of Snowflake Data Cloud applications using SAP-trusted data

Here too, the BDC Connect capabilities enables to do a zero-copy sharing of the data, avoiding data replication and keeping the context of the data..

- SAP Business Data Cloud + Databricks

Databricks is the leader in lakehouse architecture, ML/AI workloads, and open data formats. With BDC:

  • Data scientists gain business-aware SAP data without reverse-engineering SAP logic

  • ML models can be trained on harmonized SAP+non-SAP datasets

  • Semantic consistency is maintained from source to model consumption

  • Unity Catalog benefits from SAP lineage and metadata

BDC connect enables bi-directional zero-copy interoperability, including pushing curated datasets back into analytics or operational systems.

BDC connect: The Integration Accelerator

A core enabler in the ecosystem is BDC connect, providing a streamlined, governed, and high-performance integration zero-copy mechanism between SAP Business Data Cloud and modern data platforms.

With BDC connect, your data platform of choice becomes SAP-aware by design.

To summarize :

BDC ensures your modern data platforms stop treating SAP as just another source, and start treating it as a first-class, business-ready data foundation.

entry.title: From Intelligent Applications to Trusted Data: Accelerating Insight to Action for Business Analysts
entry.content:
Business analysts today are expected to turn complex datasets into insight faster than ever; analyzing trends, spotting opportunities, and ultimately providing line-of-business leaders with the information necessary to make informed decisions. To meet these demands, they need tools that simplify analysis, ensure data quality, and accelerate their path from question to actionable insight. 

At SAP TechEd 2025, SAP announced a suite of advancements designed to do just that‚Äîcontinuing to drive momentum across its data and AI portfolio. New intelligent applications, expanded access to curated data products in SAP Business Data Cloud, and deeper AI-driven assistance powered by Joule empower analysts to work smarter, make faster decisions, and deliver insights with confidence, all while maintaining governance and accuracy at every step.

Intelligent Applications: Purpose-Built Insights for Every Line of Business 

Intelligent applications in SAP Business Data Cloud continue to evolve, giving analysts prebuilt, AI-driven insights across domains like finance, HR, supply chain, and more. By embedding more intelligence directly into everyday workflows, these applications let analysts start with much of the foundational work already modeled, monitored, and enriched with AI‚Äîso they can focus on understanding trends, identifying gaps, and answering the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind the data, rather than the mechanics of assembling it.  

The Value of Intelligent Applications at a Glance: 

  • Consistent, trusted data sources resulting in reliable, repeatable insights 
  • Less manual prep work and more time spent analyzing and interpreting 
  • Shorter analysis cycles through immediate access to prebuilt dashboards 
  • Higher trust and alignment through unified metrics and premodeled insights 
  • Clearer explanations behind anomalies, trends, and performance drivers
  • AI-enhanced recommendations tailored to each line of business 

Intelligent Applications by Line of Business

Key Updates and Expanded Use Cases 

Following up on the intelligent application announcement made at SAP Sapphire in 2025, SAP has expanded both previews and general availability. Spend Intelligence, Supply Chain Intelligence, and Revenue Intelligence are now in restricted public preview, while Finance Intelligence, People Intelligence, and Cloud ERP Intelligence private packages are generally available. Together, these additions broaden the library of ready-to-use insights business analysts can tap into with minimal setup.

  • People Intelligence: New HR-focused use cases now deliver deeper insight into recruiting, learning effectiveness, and employee performance. Analysts gain more accurate attrition predictions and intuitive dashboards that make it easy to compare trends and risks across business units.  
  • Revenue Intelligence: Expanded capabilities provide revenue and sales leaders with a real-time, holistic view of pipeline performance. These updates combine continuously learning ML forecasts, automated variance detection, and unified insights across sales, finance, and operations to support more predictable planning and decision-making. 
  • Consumer Products Intelligence: A new intelligent application for consumer goods manufacturers helps optimize trade promotion planning and manage spending with greater precision. Features include real-time price elasticity analysis, promotion effectiveness insights, margin optimization tools, and streamlined workflows for executing financial operations. 

Trusted Data Products Fueling Reliable, Reusable Insights 

Data products remain one of the most impactful pillars of SAP Business Data Cloud‚Äîespecially for analysts who need quick access to context-rich and ready-to-use business data. Instead of repeatedly rebuilding the same datasets for each analysis or project, analysts can tap into governed, out-of-the-box data products that are automatically kept up to date. This not only eliminates duplication but also ensures that everyone across functional teams are working from the same source of truth. By standardizing reusable models, metrics, and pipelines, analysts gain a foundation that speeds up reporting cycles and reduces back-and-forth with technical teams. 

In summary, here's what data products bring to the table for business analysts: 

  • Reusable datasets reduce manual preparation and accelerate reporting cycles 
  • Shared metrics and models ensure consistent definitions across teams 
  • Faster insight generation with less time spent requesting or rebuilding data 
  • Increased trust in data quality, making findings easier to validate and share 

Momentum Continues: More Data Products Across SAP Applications 

SAP is expanding its catalog of ready-to-use data products across critical application areas, including SAP Cloud ERP, SAP SuccessFactors, sustainability, and customer experience. These additions will be available in SAP Business Data Cloud in H1 2026, giving business analysts access to richer, more discoverable datasets to support planning, reporting, and advanced analysis.

Overview: Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud

AI Assistants and Augmented Workflows: Work Smarter, Act Faster 

SAP‚Äôs latest advancements in AI assistants and automation deliver clear benefits to business analysts. SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) already offers strong AI capabilities, including natural language querying and machine learning-powered insights, that provide analysts with a robust foundation for faster data exploration and discovery. 

SAP is extending SAC with even more powerful, automated, and generative workflows designed to accelerate both analysis and planning: 

  • Story Generation Agent ‚Äì Automatically transforms raw data, business context, and user prompts into complete, insight-rich SAC stories or intelligent applications. It assembles visualizations, narrative structure, and recommendations using reusable components and user preferences. 
  • AI-assisted workflows for planning and analytics ‚Äì Includes comment summarization, comment translation, and natural language generation of advanced formulas. Analysts can describe complex planning logic conversationally and have SAC generate or refine the script behind it.
  • Joule embedded natively in SAC ‚Äì Provides in-context conversational support to help analysts refine queries, adjust dashboards, troubleshoot logic, or accelerate iterative analysis directly within the product. 

Joule Capabilities in SAP Analytics Cloud (2026)

Why This All Matters for Business Analysts 

Across intelligent applications, curated data products, and AI-assisted workflows, the message is clear: SAP is removing the friction that slows analysts down and elevating their work to more strategic, impactful roles. Built natively into SAP Business Data Cloud, these capabilities ensure analysts can work within a single, unified environment where data, analysis, and decision support are seamlessly connected. Analysts can now rely on workflows that are more automated, consistent, and cross-functionally integrated. The outcome: faster answers to critical business questions, clearer recommendations for business leaders, and more time spent on the high-value analytical work that drives real business impact. 

To learn more about SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP‚Äôs latest announcements: 

  • Visit SAP Business Data Cloud on sap.com 
  • Read the H2 2025 SAP Innovation Guide for key highlights 
  • Watch the replays from SAP TechEd 2025 virtual sessions: 
    • SAP Business Data Cloud solution road map (DA806v)
    • Planning and analytics: Innovations powering SAP Business Data Cloud (DA207v) 
    • Transforming how people work with Joule technology (ST123v) 
  • Get hands-on with the SAP BDC Getting Started workshop series (on-demand)

In addition, you can explore other innovations from SAP BDC by persona: for Data Stewards/Owners and Data Scientists.

entry.title: üöÄ Launch Alert! Become a Data Architecture Powerhouse: Your Foundational Learning Journey
entry.content:
To equip data professionals with the skills to bridge technical expertise and strategic business impact, SAP Data Architecture experts and the SIX learning team are thrilled to announce the launch of the Data Architect Learning Journey (Foundational). This essential first stage of the Becoming a Data Architect curriculum is designed to empower aspiring architects, data professionals, and solution experts to master the core principles, modern paradigms, and critical frameworks that define successful enterprise data architecture.

 

üèóÔ∏è Structure: Building Expertise from the Ground Up

This learning journey is structured methodically, ensuring you build expertise layer by layer, from foundational theory to strategic impact.

The journey begins with Unit 1: Foundational Concepts, where you will anchor your understanding in the essential principles of modeling, metadata management, and architectural alignment. You will master basic terminologies and fundamentals, including Conceptual, Logical, and Physical data models, and understand how data architecture integrates with enterprise frameworks like Zachman and TOGAF.

Next, Unit 2: Modern Paradigms & Integration takes you into the contemporary world of data patterns. You'll explore and compare models like Data Mesh, Data Fabric, Data Lake, and Data Lakehouse, learning how to select the right approach for any scenario. This unit also delves into integration essentials, comparing and contrasting approaches such as ETL and ELT.

Unit 3 focuses on the critical need for Governance, Security & Strategic Impact. As data ecosystems expand, governance becomes the bedrock of trust. You will learn to establish comprehensive data governance frameworks (including stewardship and data lineage) and integrate crucial security and privacy controls to ensure compliance and secure modern use cases like AI/ML.

The journey culminates in Unit 4: Communicating Data Value. A great architect is also a great leader. This final unit strengthens the communication and leadership skills needed to influence change, teaching you how to articulate the limitations of the current ("as-is") data landscape and present a compelling, business-focused narrative for the future ("to-be") architecture, focusing on quality, cost, and scale.

 

üéØWho Should Enroll? Shift from Technical Expert to Strategic Leader

This curriculum is ideal for data professionals at every stage ready to evolve from technical implementers into strategic architectural leaders. This includes Data Engineers and Modelers seeking advancement, Solution and Enterprise Architects aiming to solidify their data design expertise, BI and Analytics Professionals who need architectural context, and IT and Transformation Leaders focused on aligning data systems with business outcomes.

 

‚úÖWhy Start This Journey Now?

Modern organizations demand architects who master both technology and business value. By mastering these principles, you will gain skills that directly translate into competitive advantages: you'll improve data quality and governance, learn how to connect data architecture directly to enterprise goals, and gain the credibility needed to influence strategic decisions. Crucially, this course sets the definitive foundation for the planned SAP Certified Data Architect specialization* launching in 2026!

Visit SAP Learning and enroll in the Becoming an SAP Data Architect ‚Äì Foundational Learning Journey Today! Becoming an SAP Data Architect (Foundational)

entry.title: üöÄ Ignite Your Data Architecture Journey: Empower Enterprise and Data Architects Today!
entry.content:
In the era of digital transformation, data is the heartbeat of innovation, strategy, and impactful decision-making. Strong Data Architecture is the foundation that powers every thriving enterprise. To bridge technical expertise with strategic business outcomes, the SAP Data Architecture experts alongside the SIX learning team proudly unveil the Data Architect Learning Journey (Foundational).

This inaugural phase of the Becoming a Data Architect program is crafted to equip aspiring architects, data professionals, and solution experts with essential frameworks, modern methodologies, and core principles that shape successful enterprise data architectures.

 

üèóÔ∏è Layered Learning: From Fundamentals to Enterprise Impact

This journey guides you through a carefully designed progression to build your expertise methodically:

  • Unit 1: Foundational Concepts anchors you in the fundamentals‚Äîmastering modeling techniques, metadata management, and the integration of data architectures with enterprise frameworks such as Zachman and TOGAF. Grasp the essentials of Conceptual, Logical, and Physical models that form the backbone of data design.

  • Unit 2: Modern Paradigms & Integration immerses you in today‚Äôs evolving landscape, exploring advanced patterns like Data Mesh, Data Fabric, Data Lake, and Data Lakehouse. Understand when and how to apply each, plus gain insights into key integration frameworks, including the nuances between ETL and ELT strategies.

  • Unit 3: Governance, Security & Strategic Value addresses the growing need to establish trust and compliance within expansive data ecosystems. Delve into comprehensive data governance frameworks‚Äîdata stewardship, lineage, and privacy safeguards that secure modern architectures and enable AI/ML innovations.
