Learn to narrate the journey from the current state to future architecture, emphasizing quality, cost-efficiency, and scalability to align with business priorities.

 

üéØWho Should Embark?

Designed for data professionals ready to evolve beyond technical roles into influential architectural strategists, this foundation suits:

  • Data Engineers and Modelers aspiring to architect-level roles

  • Solution and Enterprise Architects deepening their data design acumen

  • BI and Analytics experts seeking architectural context

  • IT and Transformation leaders aligning data strategies with business goals

 

‚úÖWhy Now? Gain a Strategic Edge

Today‚Äôs enterprises demand architects who not only understand technology but who can also drive meaningful business outcomes. This journey empowers you to enhance data quality, governance, and alignment with enterprise strategies‚Äîskills that translate directly into leadership credibility and competitive advantage. Plus, it sets the stage for the upcoming SAP Certified Data Architect specialization, launching in 2026.

 

üõ£Ô∏è Begin Your Path to Architecting Tomorrow

Ready to elevate your data architectural mindset and lead transformative initiatives? No prerequisites required‚Äîstart your journey today!

Enroll now at SAP Learning: Becoming an SAP Data Architect ‚Äì Foundational Learning Journey!

entry.title: Welcome to the Data and Analytics Learning Group
entry.content:
We are very excited to launch this brand-new learning group for all learners of SAP solutions in the Data and Analytics space.

Here you can connect with SAP experts and fellow learners across all data and analytics topics.

The Data and Analytics learning group is where you can be first to learn about our plans for the introduction of new courses and the updates to existing courses. You will be first to learn about new live sessions and certification updates.

The focus of this community is learning. It is not meant to replace the existing SAP Community groups that focus on product-based discussions. Those still exist and should always be used whenever you have a question or want to discuss a topic around a product feature, or need help with trouble-shooting a product-based issue.

This learning community is a place to ask questions and join in discussions around SAP learning content such as courses, learning journeys and certification.

We are here to help you get started and to support you if you run into trouble with topics in the learning content. We are also here to help you prepare for certification. Look out for blog posts from the experts that will soon appear to help with on your learning journey.

The solutions that we cover in this community include:

  • SAP Business Data Cloud
  • SAP Datasphere
  • SAP Analytics Cloud
  • SAP Databricks
  • SAP BW and SAP BW/4HANA
  • SAP BusinessObjects
  • SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics
  • SAP HANA Modeling and Data Provisioning
  • Developing data models using ABAP CDS

The community is moderated by SAP experts who are instructors and content developers. This means that you are connecting with those who are very familiar with the course materials and certifications. Remember, these are the guys who developed them!

Make sure you click Join so that you can ask questions, jump into discussions, create blog posts, and add your responses to posts. If you don‚Äôt join you will only be able to browse the posts in this community.

Also, don‚Äôt forget to subscribe to the learning community and individual posts or tags, so you don‚Äôt miss any updates. One final thing: remember to set your notification preferences so you receive emails when a post that you subscribed to has been updated.

SAP Community provides a separate place for discussions and questions, but we thought we‚Äôd try and simply things for you by combining them. After all, a question often leads to a discussion and vice-versa. So please use the Discussions button to start a discussion and to ask questions.

Why not introduce yourself to members of this community and let us know a little about your SAP journey? What brought you here? What are you hoping to get from this community? Simply post a reply here and let us know.

Make sure you spread the word about this community. Post a link in your social media so that we can build a vibrant and effective community of data and analytics learners.

As with all SAP communities, we want this to be a safe space for our members. Please familiarize yourself with the SAP Community Rules of Engagement

Welcome aboard. Let‚Äôs get connected!

Mark Green
Moderator: SAP Community - Data and Analytics Learning Group

entry.title: Embedded Analytics for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 - List of Available Tables Reporting & Dashboard
entry.content:
SAP Sales & Service Cloud Version 2 (V2) introduces a modernized approach to analytics by embedding SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) directly into the platform. This integration provides powerful reporting and dashboard capabilities without relying on external tools, enabling real-time insights and advanced visualization options.

Note :
Embedded Analytics provided in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 is based on the embedded edition of SAP Analytics Cloud (eSAC). It is not the full version of SAP Analytics Cloud and therefore offers a limited set of functionalities compared to the standalone SAC solution.

What is Embedded Analytics in V2?

Unlike previous versions, V2 does not have native analytics. Instead, it leverages SAP Analytics Cloud, embedded edition (eSAC) as the single analytics engine across SAP solutions. This ensures:

  • Unified reporting experience across Sales and Service processes.
  • Real-time data analysis using standard V2 data sources.
  • Advanced visualization options like charts, tables, KPIs, and interactive dashboards.

Key Features

  • Design Stories Workcenter for administrators to create dashboards.
  • Analysis Workcenter for end-users to view and interact with stories.
  • Role-based access for personalized reporting.
  • Calculated Columns & Filters for custom metrics.
  • Single Sign-On (SSO) for secure access to eSAC

Available Data Sources & Tables

Embedded SAC uses the same standard data sources as native Business Analytics in v2. These include:

  • Opportunity Data (Forecast vs. Actuals)
  • Account & Contact Information
  • Activity & Interaction Logs
  • Service Tickets / Cases (Status, Escalation, Source Channels)
  • Sales Orders & Quotes
  • Lead Management Data
  • Product & Pricing Tables

Each data source can be extended with:

  • Filters (e.g., by region, status, time frame)
  • Calculated Columns (e.g., revenue variance, SLA compliance)
  • Aggregations for KPIs.

Reporting & Dashboard Capabilities

With embedded SAC, you can:

  • Build Stories combining charts, tables, and text.
  • Create Numeric Charts for KPIs like Open Tickets or Revenue.
  • Use Color Coding & Conditional Formatting for better insights.
  • Enable Drill-down Analysis for detailed exploration.
  • Share dashboards securely across teams

Benefits for Sales & Service Teams

  • Sales Managers can track pipeline health, forecast accuracy, and order conversion.
  • Service Managers can monitor ticket resolution times, escalation trends, and customer satisfaction.
  • Executives get consolidated dashboards for strategic decision-making.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in November
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in November

Another month with two great new releases ‚ú®

Learn more in my short top features video in November2025 on YouTube üì∫ and a recap from SAP TechEd this year in the blog üìù below, where you also find more details about the foundational learning journey ‚Äì Becoming an SAP Data Architect.

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

 

 

My top features in November

 

Define Row-Level Authorizations Based on IdP User Attributes

This small enhancement is very powerful and my favorite feature of November. You can now use values in custom attributes provided by your identity provider as identifiers in your data access controls and define conditions that apply to users with these values. Why is that powerful? Because using these attributes allows you to apply a single condition to all users whose accounts contain the specified attribute value. In other words, you can group users with attributes to assign permissions to a group instead of individual users.

‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

Cancel the Start or Stop Process of an Elastic Compute Node

When an elastic compute node is starting or stopping, you can now cancel the process. The data is rolled back and restored to the state that existed before the start or stop process was initially triggered.

‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

Replication Flows: Increase Maximum Parallel Job

You can increase the maximum number of parallel jobs up to 16 to run replication flows. Before, that maximum was 10, so this increase is helpful when you need more parallelization for certain flows.

More information:
‚û°Ô∏è  Configure the Size of Your SAP Datasphere Tenant and
‚û°Ô∏è  Sizing, Capacity Planning, and Load Balancing for Replication Flows

 

New Incremental Aggregation Types for Transformation Flows in a File Space

The aggregation types MIN, MAX, COUNT*, and AVG have been added to the already existing types LAST, SUM, and COUNT. 

‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

Transformation Flows: Cancel a Running Merge Task

From the Local Tables (File) monitor, you can now cancel a merge task that is running with a new Cancel button.

‚û°Ô∏è  More information.

 

Disable Delta Capture for Local Tables (File)

When creating a local table (file) from the table editor or as a target of your transformation flow, you can disable the delta capture settings.

More information:
‚û°Ô∏è  Creating a Local Table (File) and
‚û°Ô∏è  Creating a Transformation Flow in a File Space.

 

 

SAP TechEd 2025

I had the opportunity to be onsite in Berlin at SAP TechEd 2025 as well as in Sydney for SAP TechEd on tour. It was great to see so many people in person at both events. After many years of virtual TechEd‚Äôs this was excellent. Not only meeting many friends but also having those inspiring discussions with new people from various customers, partners, and also colleagues from SAP.

Session DA203 together with Dominik Kurz was recorded as part of the virtual SAP TechEd and can be watched here: 
üîó  https://www.sap.com/events/teched/virtual/flow/sap/tev25/catalog-virtual/page/catalog/session/1754495722564001nPF0

 

Happy to share that my deep dive session ‚ÄúThe impact of SAP Business Data Cloud on SAP Datasphere users‚Äù made it to the top 5 most attended sessions overall in Berlin. In general, all sessions around SAP Business Data Cloud drew high participation and our colleagues at the SAP BDC booth were also busy until the last minute on Thursday afternoon.

A highlight was certainly the partnership announcement with Snowflake. The announcement covers two flavors brownfield and greenfield scenarios.
(1) Brownfield: enabling Snowflake systems to be connected via BDC connect, targeted for GA in H1 2026
(2) Greenfield: offering SAP Snowflake on the SAP pricelist as a solution extension, targeted for Q1 2026

A week after TechEd we also announced a partnership with Microsoft at Microsoft Ignite, enabling Microsoft Fabric to be connected via BDC connect, targeted for GA in H3 2026.

That covers now Databricks, Snowflake, Google and Microsoft as technology partners for SAP Business Data Cloud Connect. Not much missing here from my point of view.

 

Becoming an SAP Data Architect - Foundational Learning Journey

 

This is a great learning opportunity for all you data architects out there‚ÄºÔ∏è
Kudos to the learning team together with our architectural experts!

The foundational Learning Journey of becoming an SAP Data Architect is the first step in a comprehensive program designed to empower data professionals and architects of the future. This new learning journey provides a structured path to develop the knowledge, frameworks, and strategic mindset needed to design, govern, and communicate enterprise-scale data architectures.

üß≠  What Is the Data Architecture Learning Journey?

The learning journey is built to create strong Data Architecture foundations moving from foundational principles to strategic business impact. Learners will gain both architectural knowledge and understanding that is essential for any modern data architect and covers the following four units:

üîπFoundational Concepts Learn the core principles and frameworks of data architecture from conceptual, logical, and physical data modelling to metadata management and frameworks.

üîπModern Paradigms & Integration Explore today‚Äôs architectural models like Data Mesh, Data Fabric, and Lakehouse and design integration strategies (ETL, ELT, and streaming) for scalable, real-time analytics.

üîπGovernance, Security & Strategic Impact Build governance frameworks, establish data lineage, safeguard privacy, and align data strategy with business objectives for measurable value.

üîπCommunicating Data Value Strengthen communication and storytelling skills to articulate architectural value, design transformation roadmaps, and drive organizational adoption of data-driven change.

‚ùì Why This Matters

In a world where data is at the core of every business decision, the role of the Data Architect has become critical.

This learning journey helps professionals at every level develop the skills, language, and strategic vision to lead in data architecture and governance.

üëâ  By completing this journey, learners will be able understand how to:

  1. Design efficient, compliant, and scalable data systems.
  2. Integrate modern architectural paradigms.
  3. Translate architecture into business value.
  4. Build narratives and roadmaps that drive transformation.

‚û°Ô∏è  How to Get Started

  1. Visit the learning.sap.com and search for ‚ÄúData Architect‚Äù OR use the Link
    üîó  https://learning.sap.com/courses/becoming-an-sap-data-architect
  2. Enroll to start your journey, Progress through the learning units at your own pace.
  3. Earn a Digital Badge on completion and share it on your socials!

And we have a lots more in store for 2026!

üîó  More information.

 

More blogs about SAP BDC and Datasphere to check out üëá

  • From MCQs to Real Skills: My Experience with SAP‚Äôs New Certification Format
  • How to activate the Object Store in SAP Datasphere?
  • Integrating Non-SAP Semi-Structured Invoices Data with SAP BDC Using SAP Databricks
  • Enhancing the Power of Customer Data through the SAP BDC Partner Ecosystem
  • Is it possible to configure scoped roles from SAP Datasphere in SAP Cloud Identity Service?
  • New Customer Influence Sessions for SAP Business Data Cloud

entry.title: SAP BTP: Data Fabric
entry.content:
Irrespective of where your source system resides, SAP provides the capabilities to ingest, harmonize and unlock real-time and predictive insights on your target system with confidence. This is supported by resilient, enterprise-grade frameworks, tools, and methodologies that safeguard data quality, integrity, and consistency throughout the entire data lifecycle.

 SAP. (2023). Figure:1

Source Systems for Data Provisioning in SAP

URL: https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-data-provisioning-in-sap-bw-4hana/identifying-sap-bw-4hana-source-systems-and-their-use-cases

 

The endless possibilities of raw, intrinsic data ingestion from e.g. Enterprise warehouses, data lakes, rational & in-memory databases, SaaS applications even social media into SAP HANA (On-premises and/ or Cloud) opens a world of opportunity for data engineers to acquire rich, accurate, and complete master and transactional data from all possible sources imaginable. Responsibility for managing the data acquisition processes depends on the provisioning type being used. Common approaches include:

Provisioning Type

Data Flow Responsibility

Metadata Management

Typical Use Cases

Application-Controlled

Source application pushes data to target using APIs or connectors.

Managed in application layer (schema, mappings, transformations).

Custom logic, application-driven workflows, SaaS integrations.

Change Data Capture (CDC)

CDC engine streams changes (insert/update/delete) from source to target in near real-time.

Managed by CDC tool (change logs, timestamps, transaction markers).

Real-time replication, incremental updates, event-driven architectures.

Database-Controlled

Target database pulls data from source using adapters or SDI.

Centralized in database layer (schemas, lineage, governance).

Governance-heavy environments, centralized data lakes, enterprise ETL.

Figure:2

Provisioning Types: Data Flow & Metadata Management

 

The utilization of high-performance ETL/ELT tools ensure the consistence, quality and reliability of the data is upheld and thus often used to unify the data to best meet the objectives of the stakeholder‚Äôs request either being executives, decision makers, marketing or product. A well-thought-out data provisioning strategy should always take precedence as this ensure a smooth flowing data process. Depending on the usage of the data, a data engineer may explorer the below different data provisioning approaches:

  • Data federation ‚Äì Data is not loaded nor persisted into the target system (SAP HANA) but rather read directly from the source system only when the data is needed for use.
  • Data replication ‚Äì Data from the source system is loaded, persisted into the target system and kept in sync using various mechanisms
    • Real-time (Synchronous) replication
    • Delta load (asynchronous)replication
  • Data transformation ‚Äì The raw data is enhanced with additional features e.g. calculation columns, renamed fields or new fields derived from other exiting fields

SAP provides but not limited to the below high-performance native data integration technologies:

Tool

Primary Function

Position in Landscape Architecture

SLT (SAP Landscape Transformation Replication)

Real-time replication (CDC)

Integration layer between SAP sources and HANA DB

SDA (Smart Data Access)

Virtual access to remote sources (federation)

Integration layer enabling query pushdown to the HANA DB

SDI (Smart Data Integration)

ETL/ELT pipelines, adapters, dataflows

Integration layer moving and transforming data before loading into the HANA DB

Figure 3:

SAP Native ETL/ELT tools

Furthermore, for Data quality, cleansing and enrichment before persisting into the HANA DB, SAP provides the below:

  • Smart Data quality (SDQ) for SAP HANA on-premises
  • Data Quality Management Microservices (DQMm) as a subscription-based microservice for SAP HANA Cloud

 

SAP Hana provides a variation of consolidated tools both on premise and in the cloud, all providing for various functionality for different use cases such as:

  • Supporting data provisioning  
  • Developing Database artefacts
  • Monitoring the performance of the develop artefacts
  • Monitoring the Database and its system performance
  • Administering and managing the Database

One of the key strengths of the SAP ecosystem is the ability to seamlessly combine cloud functionalities together with on-premises and still import specific/ needed applications as micro services into common IDE‚Äôs such as Microsoft Visual Studio code is commendable because it:

  • Provides business with a comprehensive 360-degree view of
    • Database health overview.
    • Data life cycle from end to end.
    • Application life cycle from end to end.
  • Empowers the end users, data engineers, developers, data scientists, data analyst and support engineers with greater power and flexibility over the data being used.

Below are native tools used by SAP for various purposes:

  • SAP Business Application studio ‚Äì Cloud development tool.
  • Web IDE ‚Äì On-premises development tool
  • SAP Hana cockpit - a web-based tool for monitoring, administering, and managing SAP HANA databases, offering a centralized, browser-accessible interface with tile-based dashboards for performance, resource usage (CPU, memory, disk), alerts, and security. It allows tasks like starting/stopping services, managing users, viewing alerts, analyzing performance, and running SQL queries through its integrated Database Explorer. 

SAP SaaS applications are imported into common IDE, s such as Microsoft Visual Studio code via extensions, libraries etc. for a specific purpose e.g.:

  •  Supportability tools for SAP HANA - For both online and offline performance analysis and troubleshooting. With a focus on the needs of support engineers, the performance analysis tools provide enhanced analysis options for trace files and runtime dump files, as well as allowing in-depth analysis on extensive datasets.
  • The SQL analyzer tool for SAP HANA - A performance analysis tool that helps developers visualize and understand SQL execution plans. Designed for query tuning and optimization, it offers detailed insights into how queries run within the SAP HANA database.
  • SAP HANA Database Explorer - Provides functionality for accessing SAP HANA databases, browsing the database catalog, and executing SQL from a SQL console.

Figure 4:

SAP Development and Administration Tools Overview

 

The consolidated toolset further enhances productivity and convenience for end users, data engineers, developers, data scientists, data analyst and support engineers by enabling them to access all essential capabilities from a single unified platform. The choice and flexibility to work with the desired programming languages ranging from but not limited to: SQL, SQL Script, Python, Node.js, JavaScript and react native etc. Enable a cross-functional team with diverse skill set to collaborate effectively while striving towards the same common goal.

 Figure 5:

Core Programming Languages and Frameworks for SAP HANA Cloud and On-Premises

 

After successfully completing the Explore phase, with a solid fit -to-standard analysis of proposed use cases, Extrinsic data pipelines are then implemented for reliable and consistent data flow. These pipelines support a wide range of business needs such as decision making, go-to-market activities or ML/AI use cases requested by various stakeholders. The process is typically executed and maintained by data engineers, developers, data scientists, data analyst and/or support engineers.

The harmonized data is then governed, analyzed, and visualized through multiple front-end applications. These applications are powered by various integration frameworks e.g. REST APIs, OData v4, JDBC/ODBC, each serving different user needs and functional objectives:

 Figure: 6

SAP-Compatible Applications and Their Integration Frameworks

 

Mutatis mutandis, Data is the inception of all there is, as it has been in the beginning, is now and ever shall be. Thank you all for taking a glimpse into the above Content. Please don‚Äôt for get to like, comment and share.

 

Abbreviations:

API: Application Programming Interface

BTP: Business Technology Platform

CDC: Change Data Capture

DB: Database

DQMm: Data Quality Management Microservices

ELT: Extract, Load, Transform

ETL: Extract, Transform, Load

IDE: Integrated Development Environment

ML/AI: Machine Learning/Artificial Intelligence

ODBC: Open Database Connectivity

OData: Open Data Protocol

REST: Representational State Transfer

SaaS: Software as a Service

SDI: Smart Data Integration

SDA: Smart Data Access

SDQ: Smart Data Quality

SLT: SAP Landscape Transformation Replication

SQL: Structured Query Language

 

Reference:

  1. SAP. (2023). Figure:1 Source Systems for Data Provisioning in SAP, URL: https://learning.sap.com/courses/implementing-data-provisioning-in-sap-bw-4hana/identifying-sap-bw-4hana-source-systems-and-their-use-cases

entry.title: Data masking, data scrambling and data anonymization in Business Data Cloud with SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • 1 - Generalities
  • 1.1 - Data masking
  • 1.2 - Data scrambling
  • 1.2.1 - Create function
  • 1.2.2 - Expose table data
  • 1.2.3 - Create a view
  • 1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere
  • 1.3 - Data anonymization
  • 2 - Standardization
  • 2.1 - Parameters table
  • 2.2 - SQL Procedures
  • 2.2.1 - Procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT
  • 2.2.2 - Procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR
  • 2.2.3 - Procedure EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR
  • 2.3 - Task Chain
  • 2.3.1 - Grant permissions
  • 2.3.2 - Create a task chain
  • 2.3.3 - Test
  • Conclusion

 

Introduction

This blog post was inspired from: How Data Anonymization in SAP HANA secure Generative AI applications through SAP Datasphere 

Here you will find a description of generalities about:

  • masking, scrambling and anonymization features
  • how to automate the creation of views with data masking, data scrambling and data anonymization and the possibility to activate/deactivate some features in the target views.

SAP Datasphere contains a lot of features. Some are accessible directly via its user interface and others are accessible via Open SQL Schema (see SAP Datasphere help site). Open SQL Schema gives you access to the underlying SAP HANA Cloud database, and extends the capacities offered via Datasphere's UI.

In this blog, we use a Datasphere space called DEMO with the database user DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE.

We will use a Datasphere local table SALARY as an example dataset where we would like to:

  • mask the CREDIT_CARD column and rename the column to CREDIT_CARD_MASKED,
  • scramble the NAME column and rename the column to NAME_SCRAMBLED,
  • anonymize the SALARY column and rename the column to SALARY_ANONYMIZED

 

Save the content below to import a sample dataset into the SALARY local table.

"ID","NAME","GENDER","CITY","SALARY","CREDIT_CARD"
"1","Paul McCartney","M","Levallois","1002.32","1111-1111-1111-1111"
"2","Martin Solveig","M","Munich","3218.21","2222-2222-2222-2222"
"3","Nils Lofgren","M","Nice","1398.32","3333-3333-3333-3333"
"4","Annika","F","Munich","2053.23","4444-4444-4444-4444"

 

1 - Generalities

1.1 - Data masking

Data masking is a feature implemented into SAP HANA Cloud (see Data Masking).
In this blog, we will not use privileges to manage masking, but simply use calculated SQL expressions when defining views where some columns should be masked.

To mask the content of the NAME column, we can just use the following SQL Statement into an SQL view object in Datasphere :

SELECT "ID",
   "NAME",
   CITY,
   GENDER,
   SALARY,
   LEFT(CREDIT_CARD, 4) || '-XXXX-XXXX-' || RIGHT(CREDIT_CARD, 4) AS CREDIT_CARD_MASKED
FROM SALARY

The content displayed by the view is:

 

1.2 - Data scrambling

To scramble characters in a string, a function needs to be created in the Open SQL Schema DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE (the one automatically created by Datasphere when creating the database user). To connect to this schema, SAP HANA Database Explorer can be started from the space management window:

 

1.2.1 - Create function

Once in data Database explorer, the function SCRAMBLE_STRING can be created:

Copy/Paste the following code:

CREATE FUNCTION SCRAMBLE_STRING (IN input NVARCHAR(500))
RETURNS scrambled NVARCHAR(500)
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE len INT = LENGTH(:input);
    DECLARE temp NVARCHAR(500) = :input;
    DECLARE result NVARCHAR(500) = '';
    DECLARE pos INT;
 
    WHILE LENGTH(:temp) > 0 DO
        pos := CEIL(RAND() * LENGTH(:temp));  -- Pick random position
        result := result || SUBSTRING(:temp, :pos, 1); -- Append character
        temp := REPLACE(:temp, SUBSTRING(:temp, :pos, 1), ''); -- Remove picked char
    END WHILE;
 
    scrambled := result;
  END

1.2.2 - Expose table data

Since Datasphere local tables cannot be directly exposed, in order to be able to read the content of the SALARY table when using an Open SQL Schema, a view V_SALARY needs to be created in Datasphere using the Data Builder:

SELECT "ID",
	"NAME",
	"GENDER",
	"CITY",
	"SALARY",
	"CREDIT_CARD"
FROM "SALARY"

1.2.3 - Create a view

A view V_SALARY_SCRAMBLED can now be created using Database Explorer to scramble the column NAME from the  V_SALARY view (the call to INITCAP function was just added to format names):

CREATE VIEW "V_SALARY_NAME_SCRAMBLED" AS
(SELECT 
	"ID" AS "ID",
	INITCAP(SCRAMBLE_STRING("NAME")) AS NAME_SCRAMBLED,
	GENDER AS GENDER,
	CITY AS CITY,
	SALARY,
	CREDIT_CARD
FROM DEMO.V_SALARY);

1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere

You can now import the view to create a Datasphere local table: start the process to create a dummy Datasphere view, select the Sources tab in the source browser, then click on the schema name and Drag and Drop of the View name to the text area. This triggers the table import, click on Import an Deploy, then close the New SQL View object (no need to save it, click on Discard):

Now, the view "DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE".V_SALARY_SCRAMBLED can be opened and used in Datasphere:

 

1.3 - Data anonymization

The SAP HANA Data Anonymization Guide explains how to anonymize data. In this blog, we will not focus on the technique used to anonymize data, but rather on sample syntax used to anonymize data. The following SQL code creates a view with the anonymized SALARY column (the view with anonymization will be effective after the REFRESH command):

CREATE VIEW "V_SALARY_SALARY_ANONYMIZED" AS
(SELECT 
	"ID",
	"NAME",
	GENDER,
	CITY,
	SALARY AS SALARY_ANONYMIZED,
	CREDIT_CARD
FROM DEMO.V_SALARY)
WITH ANONYMIZATION(
	ALGORITHM 'DIFFERENTIAL_PRIVACY'
	PARAMETERS '{"data_change_strategy": "qualified"}'
	COLUMN "ID" PARAMETERS '{"is_sequence": true}'
	COLUMN "SALARY_ANONYMIZED" PARAMETERS '{"is_sensitive":true, "epsilon":0.1, "sensitivity":2000}'
);
REFRESH VIEW "V_SALARY_SALARY_ANONYMIZED" ANONYMIZATION;

The V_SALARY_SALARY_ANONYMIZED view can now be imported into Datasphere (see 1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere)

2 - Standardization

We've seen above that Open SQL Schema is powerful to create features not implemented in the Datasphere UI but accessible using SQL.

The standardization will allow the SAP Datasphere users to easily activate/deactivate masking, scrambling and anonymization for columns.
A Datasphere local table (VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS) will contain the views definitions and a custom SQL procedure (EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR) will read its content to create the views based on the stored definitions. Then a Task Chain will be created to call the procedure from Datasphere.

2.1 - Parameters table

The table "VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS" will have the following columns:
  • "TARGET_VIEW": name of the view that will be created in the Open SQL Schema
  • "CONFIGURATION": characteristic of the target view. Contains the field name of the unmasked, scrambled anonymized field
  • "SEQ": optional sequence number used to order the list of the view fields
  • "VALUE": value related to the "CONFIGURATION". When "CONFIGURATION" is a field name, it contains an expression (or NULL when the field doesn't need to be changed in the target view) 
  • "CREATE": 'YES' when the target field needs to be created in the target table
  • "RENAME_TO": target field name when "CONFIGURATION" field name needs to be changed
  • "ACTIVATE": 'YES' when the target field "VALUE" needs to be used (when it doesn't start with the keyword 'PARAMETERS'). Otherwise the field name stored in "CONFIGURATION" is used.
CONFIGURATION contains one of the following keywords:
  • '#EXECUTE#': define the behavior of the procedure that will create the target view. When "VALUE" contains the value:
    • 'YES': it creates in the "TARGET_VIEW" view the fields with the 'CREATE' value set to 'YES'
    • 'ALL': it ignores the value of the "ACTIVATE" field ; all the fields with the 'CREATE' value set to 'YES' will be created with the expression stored in "CONFIGURATION"
    • 'RESET': if ignore the value of the "ACTIVATE" field ; all the fields with the 'CREATE' value set to 'YES' will be created with their original definition stored in "VALUE"
  • '#SOURCE_NAME#': when used, then "VALUE" contains the name of the table/view used to create the target view
  • '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#': when used, then VALUE contains the expression used for anonymization (see SAP HANA Data Anonymization Guide)

 

In the previous screenshot, the view V_SALARY_DERIVED will have the following fields and properties:

  • "ID" will remain unchanged
  • "NAME" will be scrambled and renamed to "NAME_SCRAMBLED"
  • "GENDER" will appear not changed in the target view
  • "CITY" will not appear in the target view
  • "SALARY" will be anonymized and renamed to "SALARY_ANONYMIZED"
  • "CREDIT_CARD" will be masked and renamed to "CREDIT_CARD_MASKED"

In order to execute the expressions to create the target columns, a line with '#EXECUTE#' was created.
Since the view contains anonymized data, a line with '#ANONYZATION_TYPE#' was s created.

In order to be able to use this table content into an Open SQL Schema, an SQL view in SAP Datasphere needs to be created : V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS. This view will contain all the fields from the table.

 

2.2 - SQL Procedures

Three SQL procedures are created:

  • EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT: generates a create view statement 
  • EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR: with a string parameter used to filter the view V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS to create only one target view by calling the procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT and embedding the code with instructions to drop the view if it already exists and generates the REFRESH statement if anonymization is used.
  • EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR: calls EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR for the distinct values of TARGET_VEWS.

2.2.1 - Procedure  EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT

This procedure returns the CREATE VIEW statement for one target view defined in the view "VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS" .

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
CREATE PROCEDURE EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT (
	IN TARGET_NAME_ VARCHAR(1000),
	IN CURRENT_SPACE_ VARCHAR(1000),
	IN CURRENT_SCHEMA_ VARCHAR(1000),
	IN EXECUTE_ VARCHAR(1000),
	OUT FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ INTEGER,
	OUT SQL_DDL VARCHAR (2500)
)
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE PART1 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART2 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART3 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART4 VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE PART5 VARCHAR(2500);

	/*
	CREATE VIEW PART 1: begining part to create the target view
	*/
    SELECT TOP 1 'CREATE VIEW '||:CURRENT_SCHEMA_||'.'|| :TARGET_NAME_ AS x
    into PART1 
    FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
    WHERE "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

	/*
	CREATE VIEW PART 2: list columns for the target view
	*/
	WITH VIEW_PARAMETERS as
		(SELECT
			"TARGET_VIEW" AS "TARGET_VIEW",
			"CONFIGURATION" AS "CONFIGURATION",
			"SEQ" AS "SEQ",
			CASE :EXECUTE_ 
				WHEN 'YES' 
					THEN CASE WHEN IFNULL("ACTIVATE", 'NO')<>'YES'
						THEN "CONFIGURATION"
						ELSE "VALUE"
					END
				WHEN 'ALL' THEN "VALUE"
				WHEN 'RESET' THEN "CONFIGURATION" 
			END AS "VALUE",
			"CREATE" AS "CREATE",
			"RENAME_TO" AS "RENAME_TO"
		FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS
		WHERE "CONFIGURATION" NOT IN ('#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#', '#EXECUTE#', '#SOURCE_NAME#')
			AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_
		)
    SELECT ' ( ' ||
	    string_agg( IFNULL(RENAME_TO,"CONFIGURATION" )
	    	    , ', ' ORDER BY "SEQ" ) ||
	    ' ) as select ' ||
	    string_agg( 
	        IFNULL(
	            ( CASE WHEN "VALUE" LIKE 'PARAMETERS%' 
					THEN NULL 
					ELSE "VALUE" 
	            END ) 
	            , "CONFIGURATION"
	        ) ||
			' as ' ||
			IFNULL( RENAME_TO, "CONFIGURATION" )
			, ', ' ORDER BY "SEQ"
		) 
    AS x 
    INTO PART2
    FROM VIEW_PARAMETERS
    WHERE "CREATE" = 'YES';
    
	/*
	CREATE VIEW PART 3: select expression for the target view
	*/
	SELECT TOP 1 ' from '|| :CURRENT_SPACE_ || '.' || "VALUE" 
	as x 
	into PART3 
	FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
	WHERE "CONFIGURATION" = '#SOURCE_NAME#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

	WITH VIEW_PARAMETERS as
		(SELECT
			"TARGET_VIEW" AS "TARGET_VIEW",
			CASE :EXECUTE_ 
				WHEN 'YES' 
					THEN CASE WHEN IFNULL("ACTIVATE", 'NO')<>'YES'
						THEN "CONFIGURATION"
						ELSE "VALUE"
					END
				WHEN 'ALL' THEN "VALUE"
				WHEN 'RESET' THEN "CONFIGURATION" 
			END AS "VALUE"
		FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS
		WHERE "CONFIGURATION" NOT IN ('#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#', '#EXECUTE#', '#SOURCE_NAME#')
			AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND "CREATE"='YES'
			AND EXISTS (SELECT 1 
						FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
						WHERE UPPER("CONFIGURATION") = '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND :EXECUTE_ in ('YES','ALL')
						)
		)
	SELECT count(*) as x
	INTO FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_
	FROM VIEW_PARAMETERS
	WHERE "VALUE" LIKE 'PARAMETERS%' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;
	
	IF :FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ <> 0 THEN
		/*
		CREATE VIEW PART 4: add predicate for anonymization
		*/
	    SELECT "VALUE" AS x 
	    INTO PART4 
	    FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
	    WHERE "CONFIGURATION" = '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;
	
		/*
		CREATE VIEW PART 5: list parameters for anonymization
		*/
		WITH VIEW_PARAMETERS as
		(SELECT
			"TARGET_VIEW" AS "TARGET_VIEW",
			"CONFIGURATION" AS "CONFIGURATION",
			"SEQ" AS "SEQ",
			CASE :EXECUTE_ 
				WHEN 'YES' 
					THEN CASE WHEN IFNULL("ACTIVATE", 'NO')<>'YES'
						THEN "CONFIGURATION"
						ELSE "VALUE"
					END
				WHEN 'ALL' THEN "VALUE"
				WHEN 'RESET' THEN "CONFIGURATION" 
			END AS "VALUE",
			"RENAME_TO" as "RENAME_TO"
		FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS
		WHERE "CONFIGURATION" NOT IN ('#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#', '#EXECUTE#', '#SOURCE_NAME#')
			AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND "CREATE"='YES'
			AND EXISTS (SELECT 1 
						FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS 
						WHERE UPPER("CONFIGURATION") = '#ANONYMIZATION_TYPE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_ AND :EXECUTE_ in ('YES','ALL')
						)
		)
		SELECT string_agg('Column ' || IFNULL(RENAME_TO,"CONFIGURATION") || ' ' || "VALUE", ' ' ORDER BY "SEQ") ||' )' AS x
	    INTO PART5
	    FROM VIEW_PARAMETERS
	    WHERE UPPER(LEFT("VALUE",10))='PARAMETERS' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;
		
	END IF;	   
	
    select string_agg(x, ' ' order by rn) as x 
    into SQL_DDL from (
	    SELECT :PART1 as x ,1 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL
	    SELECT :PART2 as x ,2 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL
	    SELECT :PART3 as x ,3 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL
	    SELECT :PART4 as x ,4 as rn from DUMMY UNION ALL    
	    SELECT :PART5 as x ,5 as rn from DUMMY
    ) a ;
END

 

2.2.2 - Procedure  EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR

This procedure creates the SQL instructions to create one target view.

It contains:

  • a DROP command that will be executed if the TARGET_VIEW is already existing
  • a CREATE VIEW command to create the TARGET_VIEW
  • A REFRESH command if TARGET_VIEW contains any field that needs to be anonymized

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
CREATE PROCEDURE EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR (IN TARGET_NAME_ VARCHAR (1000)) 
AS
BEGIN
    DECLARE SQL_DROP VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE SQL_DDL VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE EXECUTE_ VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE REFRESH_ VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE FLAG_DROP_ INTEGER;
    DECLARE FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ INTEGER;
    DECLARE CURRENT_SCHEMA_ VARCHAR(2500);
    DECLARE CURRENT_SPACE_ VARCHAR(2500);

SELECT UPPER("VALUE") as x into EXECUTE_ FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS WHERE UPPER("CONFIGURATION") = '#EXECUTE#' AND "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

IF :EXECUTE_ IN ('YES', 'RESET', 'ALL') THEN
	SELECT 'DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE' into CURRENT_SCHEMA_ FROM DUMMY;
	SELECT SUBSTR_BEFORE(:CURRENT_SCHEMA_, '#') into CURRENT_SPACE_ from DUMMY;
    SELECT count (*) INTO FLAG_DROP_ FROM views WHERE schema_name=:CURRENT_SCHEMA_ and view_name=:TARGET_NAME_;
   
    /*
    DROP SQL expression to premare the replacement for the target view.
    */
    SELECT TOP 1 'DROP VIEW '||:CURRENT_SCHEMA_||'.'||:TARGET_NAME_ ||' ; ' as x 
    into SQL_DROP
    from DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS WHERE "TARGET_VIEW"=:TARGET_NAME_;

    /*
    CREATE SQL expression to create the target view.
    */
	CALL "DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE"."EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR_CREATE_STATMT"(
		TARGET_NAME_ => :TARGET_NAME_ /*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		CURRENT_SPACE_ => :CURRENT_SPACE_ /*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		CURRENT_SCHEMA_ => :CURRENT_SCHEMA_ /*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		EXECUTE_ => :EXECUTE_/*<NVARCHAR(1000)>*/,
		FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ => FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_,
		SQL_DDL => SQL_DDL
	);
	
	IF :FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ <> 0 THEN    
	    /*
	    REFRESH SQL expression for anonymization feature.
	    */
	    SELECT 'REFRESH VIEW '|| :CURRENT_SCHEMA_ ||'.'|| :TARGET_NAME_ || ' ANONYMIZATION;'
	    INTO REFRESH_ 
	    FROM DUMMY ;
	END IF;

    IF FLAG_DROP_ <> 0 THEN 
        EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SQL_DROP;
    END IF;

    EXECUTE IMMEDIATE SQL_DDL;
    IF :FLAG_ANONYMIZATION_ <> 0 THEN
    	EXECUTE IMMEDIATE REFRESH_;
    END IF;

END IF;
END

2.2.3 - Procedure  EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR

This procedure calls the procedure EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR for all the distinct values for TARGET_VIEW.

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
CREATE PROCEDURE EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR()
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
AS
BEGIN
	DECLARE CURSOR c_cursor FOR SELECT DISTINCT TARGET_VIEW FROM DEMO.V_VIEWS_CREATOR_PARAMETERS;
	FOR rec as c_cursor
	DO
	    CALL "DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE"."EXEC_VIEWS_CREATOR" (:rec.TARGET_VIEW);
  END FOR;
END

2.3 - Task Chain

In order to be autonomous to mask, scramble and anonymize data in Datasphere (without accessing to the Open SQL Schema) a task chain can be created to call the SQL procedure EXEC_ALL_VIEWS_CREATOR.

2.3.1 - Grant permissions

Datasphere space needs to view and run the SQL Procedure that was created in the Open SQL Schema, some grants need to be done in SQL Developer by  the user DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE to the Datasphere space user.

In the code below:

  • replace DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE with the name of your Open SQL Schema
  • replace DEMO with your Datasphere space name.
 
CALL "DWC_GLOBAL"."GRANT_PRIVILEGE_TO_SPACE" (
	OPERATION => 'GRANT', 
	PRIVILEGE => 'EXECUTE', 
	SCHEMA_NAME => 'DEMO#USER_ANONYMIZE', 
	OBJECT_NAME => '', 
	SPACE_ID => 'DEMO');

2.3.2 - Create a task chain

 

2.3.3 - Test

For testing purposes, we can use the parameters table described in 2.1 - Parameters table .

After running the task chain, the view V_SALARY_DERIVED was created and can now be imported into the Datasphere space (see 1.2.4 - Import the view into Datasphere ).

Finally your space should contain this list of objects: 

 

If you open V_SALARY_DERIVED:

 

Conclusion

If you face some missing features in Datasphere, consider Open SQL Schema, it may offer you the opportunity to implement what you miss using the underlying SAP HANA Cloud database.

If you liked this blog, say it by clicking on the Like button.

entry.title: Rewiring of SAP Datasphere to SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
The rewiring of existing SAP Datasphere tenants to SAP Business Data Cloud has become available in 2025. Since then, I have been in many discussions with customers, partners, but also SAP colleagues at SAP TechEd in Berlin, Sydney and other events or meetings.

I observed that people unintentionally misinterpret the term ‚Äúrewiring‚Äù. It sounds technical, hence there are associations with data, object or even full tenant migrations. This is not the case!

Let me use this blog to clarify what rewiring is, and what it is not. Moreover, give you some guidance on the steps which you need to take.

 

‚ÄÉ

When do I need to rewire my existing SAP Datasphere tenant?

You have made a decision to sign up for SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and to make use of your existing tenants for SAP Datasphere and / or SAP Analytics Cloud as part of your new landscape with SAP BDC.

If you have not made any decision on SAP BDC yet, you can certainly use your existing tenant(s) until the end of your current contract without SAP BDC. However, you will miss out on new capabilities offered by SAP BDC with SAP managed data products and the enhanced open partner ecosystem options.

 

What is tenant rewiring?

The term ‚Äúrewiring‚Äù sounds quite technical. Therefore, there are immediate associations with data, object or even full tenant migrations. This is not the case!

  1. The term rewiring mainly refers to a change of your commercial model from a stand-alone tenant to a tenant which is managed as part of a larger SAP BDC landscape.
  2. Rewiring helps you change the management of your tenant lifecycle to the SAP for Me portal.
  3. Prerequisites are that you commercially move the tenant on your same customer ID and your current data center being available also for Business Data Cloud. Please check on these two points!
  4. If these conditions are met a lot will stay the same. Meaning you stay on your existing hyperscaler and data center. Hence, your tenant and its URL will remain intact, just under a new commercial model, even without any downtime required.

 

What is tenant rewiring not?

Rewiring is therefore not a tenant migration as your existing tenant stays the same and is reused as part of an SAP BDC landscape.

Rewiring does not migrate your tenant between hyperscalers or data centers, as with the conditions mentioned before, your current data center ‚Äì given that it is available for SAP BDC ‚Äì will stay the same on your existing customer ID.

Rewiring does not migrate your data or any objects, as the full existing tenant is only commercially moved as described before.

Rewiring does not require any tenant downtime.

 

How can I initiate a tenant rewiring?

Before you can start to initiate the rewiring, you need to change the commercial model of your SAP Datasphere tenant to a Business Data Cloud contract ‚Äì in short: a subscription to SAP Business Data Cloud must exist.

For tenants provisioned via BTP cockpit

After the commercial change, your SAP BTP administrator can initiate the tenant rewiring directly through the SAP BTP platform global account as a self-service. You control the timing of rewiring yourself, as you can trigger it via self-service.

Once the request is received, the process is initiated to update the tenant and move it to SAP Business Data Cloud. The tenant will be visible in SAP Business Data Cloud when the rewiring is completed.

For subscription tenants provisioned by SAP

After the commercial change, your subscription is moved from standalone to SAP Business Data Cloud. Be aware, that the SAP Business Data Cloud cockpit feature must be activated in your appropriate data center through SAP for Me portal prior to rewiring.

The rewiring itself is initiated as part of the subscription change request. That means, your tenant is automatically moved to SAP Business Data Cloud for the contract start date.

 

Where do I find more detailed information?

For more details I recommend these three resources:

SAP Community Blog by @Ammar_Naji:
üîó UPDATE: SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Availability via SAP Business Data Cloud

SAP Help documentation for detailed steps:
üîó  Rewiring of Standalone SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud Subscriptions to SAP Business Data Cloud

üîó  SAP Note 3650483

 

Let me know if there are still questions about rewiring and post them below üëá in the comments section. I will try to answer them and loop in colleagues in case I do not know the answer myself.

entry.title: Authorization setup for SAC Import Model from S4 ABAP CDS Views
entry.content:
Purpose of this document

The purpose of this blog is to explain how to implement data-level authorization in SAP Analytics Cloud Stories when:

  • Data is extracted from SAP S/4HANA CDS Views
  • The connection type is Import Model
  • Authorization must be enforced based on Company Code and Plant

This approach ensures that users can access only the data they are authorized to see, even though the data is physically stored in SAC.

 

Business Use Case

In many finance and controlling scenarios:

  • A single SAC Story is shared across multiple business users
  • Users belong to different Company Codes and Plant
  • Data is periodically imported from SAP S/4HANA into SAC

Since Import Models store data in SAC, runtime authorisation from S/4HANA (CDS DCLs) is not applied. Therefore, authorization must be designed and enforced within SAC.

 

Authorization Concept for Import Models

When working with SAC Import Models, authorization is handled as follows:

Layer

Responsibility

SAP S/4HANA CDS

Defines which data is extracted

SAC Model

Enforces row-level data authorization

SAC Story

Automatically respects model-level security

Key points to note:
  • CDS DCLs are evaluated only at data extraction time
  • SAC Data Access Control (DAC) governs user visibility
  • Story designers do not need to manage authorization logic
Example Used in This Blog

The same example is used consistently throughout the blog.

Attribute

Value

Authorization Dimensions

Company Code, Plant

Sample Company Code

0100

Sample Plant

RA01, RA02, ‚Ä¶

SAC Connection Type

Import

Source System

SAP S/4HANA CDS View

 

Step-by-Step Authorization Setup

Step 1: Prepare CDS View in SAP S/4HANA

Ensure that the CDS View contains the fields required for authorization, i.e., Company Code and Plant.

Example CDS Used:

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZCDEMO002V'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Demo Authorization Consumption VIew'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Analytics.query: true
@VDM.viewType: #CONSUMPTION
define view ZC_DEMO_AUTH_2
  as select from ZI_DEMO_AUTH_1
{
  PurchaseOrder,
  PurchaseOrderItem,
  PurchaseOrderCategory,
  CompanyCode, // Authorization field
  Plant,       // Authorization Field
  @Semantics.currencyCode: true
  DocumentCurrency,
  @DefaultAggregation: #SUM
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'DocumentCurrency'
  PurOrderNetAmount
}

Important notes:

  • Authorization-relevant fields must be part of the CDS output
  • CDS DCLs are not used for runtime authorization in SAC Import Models

 

Step 2: Create Import Model in SAP Analytics Cloud

  • Navigate to Connections in SAC.
  • Create an SAP S/4HANA Import Connection.
  • Import the CDS View as a Model.

  • At this stage, the data is physically stored in SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

Step 3: Enable Data Access Control (DAC)

  • Open the imported Model
  • Navigate to Settings
  • Navigate to Model Preferences
  • Enable Data Access Control

  • This step activates row-level authorization for the model.

 

Step 4: Mark Authorization-Relevant Dimensions

  • Enable data access control for the required dimensions.
  • Select CompanyCode, and Plant.

  • These dimensions are now evaluated during data access.

 

Step 5: Create Data Access Roles

  • Navigate to Security ‚Üí Data Access
  • Create a new Data Access Role

  • Provide Role information, Role template, and review before creating. Template helps to create roles fast for general sections like BI Admin or Planner. In this we will choose template as ‚ÄòBlank‚Äô.

  • After role is created, we will move to ‚ÄòSelect Model‚Äô, choose your import model.

  • Select dimensions required for authorizations and provide values for each.

 

Step 6: Assign Data Access Role to Users

  • Navigate to Security ‚Üí Roles
  • Select the relevant user
  • Assign Business Role ‚Äì SAC_ROLE_DEMO_001 to users for Row-level authorization.
  • The user now inherits Company Code and Plant restrictions.

 

Step 7: Validate Authorization in SAC Story

  • Create or open a Story based on the model.
  • Add a table or chart in story for validation.
  • Include Company Code and Plant as dimensions.
  • Authorization is automatically enforced at runtime.

 

Results

After completing the setup:

  • Data visibility is restricted at row level.
  • A single Story can be reused for multiple user groups.
  • No duplication of Stories or Models is required.
  • Authorization is centrally managed in SAC.
  • Import performance remains unchanged.

 

Best Practices

  • Enable Data Access Control immediately after model creation.
  • Use consistent authorization dimensions across models.
  • Follow clear and business-aligned naming conventions for roles.
  • Do not rely on CDS DCLs for Import Model security.
  • Always validate authorization using multiple test users.

 

Conclusion

When working with SAP Analytics Cloud Import Models based on SAP S/4HANA CDS Views, authorization must be implemented within SAC.

By using:

  • Data Access Control
  • Authorization-enabled dimensions
  • Data Access Roles

you can achieve secure, scalable, and reusable Story-level authorization based on Company Code and Plant fully aligned with standard SAP practices.
